reviewText:
hi! this review mainly serves to inform buyers about the differences between the PC version of this game, and the console version which it is a port version of.
i have played both PC and console (PS3) versions of the game. i played the PS3 version at launch and PC version this year.

PC Pros:

+ ALICE supports graphics enhancing injectors such as SweetFX, so if you are comfortable using this type of program and have the specs for it, you can have a higher graphical quality experience than is at all possibly attainable on the PS3 (and despite the slightly outdated graphics, this is still an awesome game from an aesthetic perspective!)

+ if your hobby is sceenshotting games, or even recording gameplay videos, it's probably a no-brainer due to this that you would want a PC copy of ALICE simply because it's a lot more convenient and doesn't rely on the preset specs of a clunky console.

+ if you don't mind adding some quick lines of code (see comments for how) to the config files of the game (which you can do with any txt-type word processor) this will also unlock many preset outfits for Alice to wear as alternates to her story-mode outfits, and these come with interesting buffs and debuffs (for harder and easier mode play)

+ in general: the emotiveness, clever dialogue and creativity of the entire game is ever-present, and both the combat and noncombat scenarios are often blissfully relaxing as they are at other times a trifle vexing.

PC Cons:

- the game was supposed to come with a bonus" hidden file containing the original American McGee's Alice game in addition to ALICE MADNESS... unfortunately

The mythology of Alice, Lewis Carroll's inquisitive young heroine thrust into a psychedelic kaleidoscope of strange yet unsettlingly familiar characters, has changed hands and changed costumes many, many times since Carroll penned Alice's Adventures In Wonderland[en.wikipedia.org] and Through The Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There[en.wikipedia.org] at the end of the 19th century. I personally love the original story and that's pretty much where my head first goes when Alice is mentioned. reviewText:
A beautiful game. I truly mean every word when I say: Every environment is stylized, enchanting, made of peculiar objects born within Alice's mind. It makes truly amazing and unique landscapes. The enemies too are very well done.

The music is amazing too, many songs I will remember.

It has flaws, the combat, while fairly fun, is simple, there are few combos, you can change between your melee weapons while hitting, so it's nothing disastrous, it's fairly solid, but it does get repetitive. The game is also plagued with random minigame segments. Thanks to EA pushing the studio for early release.

Still, the game is amazing, the story is one of the most ballsy a game could have. It is one of my favorites.

Get this small masterpiece.

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Nightmare fetishist
Alice has finally been released from the Asylum to the Orphanage convinced that she herself started the fire which killed her parents and sister. Racked with guilt that is slowly driving her towards the brink of insanity she once again descends into the imaginative world of Wonderland looking for some comfort with old friends but with her mind fast unraveling the Wonderland of her childhood has now fully transformed itself into a dark cellar of a world filled with the grotesque and unimaginable.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=149704525
Alice: Madness Returns is a mixture of platforming, puzzle-solving, adventuring with more than a touch of horror. The games earlier scenes are visually stunning as we move from a grey 1800's London to the lush beauty of the Vale. The differences in color palette used is so striking that for a minute you will almost believe that this safe haven for Alice's shattered mind is the rightful place to recuperate. It doesn't take long, however, before Wonderland starts to distort and disfigure itself.

It's a pity that those striking sequences aren't matched by what follows as Alice visits three area's in succession that diminish the power of the opening stages - The Mad Hatter's Domain, the Deluded Depths and the Oriental Grove (with the Grove looking particularly under developed and rushed with terrible textures everywhere - in fact it looks like an entire different team developed this section as it doesn't match the quality of the other areas). It was at this point that I was getting weary and a bit tired of Alice's shenanigans and her search to find out the truth about what actually happened to her parents that she initiates once in Wonderland by cleverly having to collect memories of her childhood that slowly piece together the events that led to her family's death.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=148814210
I am glad I stayed along for the ride because Alice really shows off its strength in the last two areas of the game - Queensland and the Doll House. These two areas are such a horrifying joy to explore (and I mean horrifying with the Queen of Hearts castle literally blood-soaked or being attacked by dolls with missing eyes and limbs during the Doll house sequence). It's during these stages that Alice really hits its creative stride soaring past the earlier levels in design and creativity. If I have one gripe during these magnificent levels, its seems as if the game itself has gotten much, much easier posing very little in the way of a challenge.

Towards the end of the game things take a decidedly darker turn with quite the disturbing twist in the tale. I won't spoil it for the gamer out there who still wants to get the full experience but suffice to say that by the time the Doll's House rolls around the imagery should already start preparing you for where the story is actually headed. Buckle up - because we are headed straight into the heart of darkness.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=226092373
The game is also a very long one - it took me 18hrs to complete and that time does not include searching for all the collectibles on each level. The game's soundtrack is also truly immersive managing to hit all the right notes to keep you audibly invested in the adventure even though Alice: Madness Returns is a game of two halves - one utterly brilliant and so imaginative that I could lose myself to a larger gaming world just comprised of those areas and the other feeling completely soulless and devoid of any charm. But itâ€™s still worth the experience just for the last two acts alone.

reviewText: The overall quality of Alice: Madness Returns is high, despite it feeling rushed. The qualities that made American McGee's Alice so enjoyable-the gory hack-'n'-slash combat, the gorgeous design, the rich dialogue, the menacing mood-are present and abundant.Alice: Madness Returns is a dream come true for fans of American McGee's Alice. It's a worthy heir and at the same time a fully modern game that can vie with the best contemporary representatives of this genre. It's long, it's difficult, it's rewarding and enchanting.Alice: Madness Returns is a wolf in sheep's clothing. This game may look honest and cute, but it's cruel and bloody.Alice: Madness Returns may not win awards for genre innovation, but it's the most darkly fun and gloriously batty game I've played.It's not perfect, but it's as close to the definition of masterpiece as it could be. A thrilling and exciting adventure to the dark corners of Wonderland.

reviewText: A frantic third person action game featuring a darker version of Lewis Carrol's Alice. Or maybe it was already dark enough until disney molested the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out of it because you know, for kids. The sequel picks up years after the original where Alice is a grown woman now, having defeated the madness that plagued her mind. Or so it seems. Wherever it lacks in variety and innovation, it makes up with numerous gorgeous places to explore, bizzare characters and enemies to meet, and a captivating story that unfolds itself through Alice's madness in the most beautiful and sinister way at the same time. American McGee did it again just like he did with the original game over a decade ago. A must for the fans of the original; newcomers, tread carefully.\n7/8

reviewText:
TLDR: Game is beautiful, story is intresting and atmospheric, but gameplay streches too long and some parts will be boring and monotone - game is often on sale, a -75% usual one is GREAT to pick the game up. Don't bother with full price, I don't think it's worth it.
According to Steam I've played this for the whopping amount of 36.9 hours - ingame timer says 16 hours, 91% completion.
About this game: picked up a copy for a friend to return a friendly gesture and at the same time I bought it for myself, because I was really intrested in it (Alice + implementation of madness? Yes please, I'm in!)
The game starts out wonderful. You'll keep making screenshots - the game world is really nicely designed and well-executed, some landscapes are jaw-dropping both in terms of quality and creativity.
Platforming works great, there are no issues with controls - but after a time it can be boring, because most chapters (5 looong chapters, all in 1-2 different settings than the others) use quite the same mechanics/ideas as precious ones, only re-skinned.
Combat is both lacking and feels rewarding. Why?  Personally I really miss combos and airbone attacks. Maybe I'm too new for the third-person platformers, but I think while combat plays a really central part in the gameplay, it could have been much better.  And why is it still great? You have 4 weapons - basically a light and heavy variant of melee and ranged. As most things, the weapons look astonishingly good, with real nice sound - and visual effects. But the biggest and best thing of combat system is the really different enemies. They all work in their own way - one is easy to take on with the pepper-grinder (machine gun), the other one's weakness is the heavy Hobby Horse's armor-breaking hits. Each enemy, and especially their mixed groups require different tactics to defeat them.  It's a little shame that by the time you finish a chapter, most likely you'll be bored of the enemies - the first Samurai Wasp is challenging, the third is an intresting enemy, but you'll stomp on the 8th one. Not to mention the 20th one.
Level design: Gorgeous. In chapter 2? you'll go into a snowy landscape, to end up in a ship-in-a-bottle, only to get it sunk then continue your journey underwater. Another chapter is all about Japan and the East - koi pond, china-landscape, traditional fans.  Chapter 4 and 5 are just incredible and maybe the best ones from the game, both in terms of gameplay and design. If only chapter 2 and 3 would be similarly good.
Though there is one thing that can put a dent on the experience: invisible walls everywhere. You can't touch most of the walls because you'll stop running ~ 30 cm before them, you can't jump on most things because pleasantly placed invisible ~2-3 metre tall boxes" are placed on them because you only can jump on something you're *supposed* to jump on. It's a shame in a game from 2011.
Minigames! There are various minigames/ tasks in the game you need to complete to continue: chess puzzle

reviewText: If you want this game because you think it's a cutesy little Alice in Wonderland game, then don't buy this game. If you want it because you want to play as a crazed lunatic who battles the demons in her head in a last ditch attempt to safe herself from insanity, and recover the truth about the death of her parents, then get a move on and get it, because it is frickin' brilliant.\n\nAmerican Mcgee's twisted art style is just perfect for this game, and whilst some people might start finding the gameplay a little tedious towards the end, I think the combat is very well done, and the world surrounding you should make you want to carry on and see what other crazy things are gonna happen. As well as the art you've got a bunch of collectibles to find, like bottles, memories and flying pig snouts. (Literally). Alice also has the ability to shrink herself, revealing platforms and passages, which is downright awesome. It's games like this that make the real world seem pointless.

reviewText:
Dear Alice,

I find you dark and beautiful. You took me to place that I've never seen before and yet were hauntingly familiar. Introduced me to friends that I could have sworn I had met, and yet were different and twisted. Ours could have been a love affair for the ages.

Now, four years after we should have met, I've followed you down the dark and twisting road of your past. I fell in love with you at first sight. You told me the horrific story of your past and for a time I sat raptured. I have so many good things to say about you. You're smart and graceful. Your movement is like a gazelle. You showed me places M.C. Escher would be proud to call his own. And yet, and yet.

The truth is Alice, you don't know when to leave. I wanted to hear your story. I wanted to visit all the dark places that you promised me that we would go. I have to admit that you delivered on your promises. Each place we went was more interesting, darker, and haunting then the last. You just wouldn't leave. Every intersting thing you showed me you had to show me three or four times.

As intelligent as I find you to be, your repitition was heartbreaking. The amazing thing is that your repitition was per location, not overall. As much as I wanted every time we met to be a joy, I found myself starting to resent you. I started to wish we could just finish this part and move on to the next visage that awaited. I knew that if I stuck it out, the next local, the next piece of the puzzle of your mind that you opened up to me would be amazing. It was just such a long time between one revelation and when you would open up to me again that I started to wonder if it was worth the time I was spending getting to know you.

You had so many interesting insights, so many variations on how you viewed the world I wish that I could look past your refusal to grind through each and every insight multiple times. I wish, I wish, I wish.

Dear, Dear Alice. You have so much to offer. Maybe it's not you, maybe its me. If another chap came up and asked me about you I would tell him how lovely you are. I would tell him how smart and charming you can be. I fear that after a few pints I would probably tell him that I just had a hard time with how long you would drag through any given situation. That the revelations were inticing, but the fluff between revelations didn't make me anticpate the revleations more, just make me resent the fluff.

Love,

Kuasimoddo

P.S. I am tentatively telling my friends you are a cool chick with the caveat that you waaaaay overstay your welcome.

reviewText:
I invite you to a world where there is no such thing as time. And every creature lends themselves to change your state of mind...
I finished this game about a week ago and for an old game it's pretty damn good tbh. Alice's past is pretty harsh and she dwells on it all the time thus her wonderland is falling apart.. again. And she must go into the depths of her mind to find the problem that's scratching at her sanity and execute it.
I absolutely loved the scenery and artwork of this game the most. The levels were not too long but not too short either. And each chapter has so many secret rooms and hidden items. The storyline could have been a bit more compelling but it was still pretty good imo. It does have some decent plot twists.
The game definitely has a pretty creepy feel to it and the enemies seem like something out of a horror movie as well. Some enemies can be very frustrating at first but once you get a good system on how to kill them then it's not so bad. The puzzles in the game were definitely a wide variety of fun, like how they should be in most games. They weren't too easy and they weren't so hard and/or confusing that it would just â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you off.
One of my favorite aspects of the game were the weapons. Which you can also upgrade the weapons over time by collecting teeth.
The characters in the game were just awesome. Ofc you have the ones you know like Mad Hatter, The Queen, Chester Cat, etc. The voice acting was spot on to the character's personalities as well and very good facial expressions.
Another thing I thought was a really nice touch, was Alice's outfits. Each chapter she would change into a different dress and they would match the scenery of the current level.

Also. I would eat Alice's green eyes. Even though I have green eyes myself, but... I just like her eyeballs. à² _à² 

The only complaint I really have about the game is that it can be a bit buggy. Sometimes when you kill an enemy it might move about like it's still kickin, but the game is just being derpy and the enemy will just disappear eventually. The only bug I had a real issue with (and others had issues on it too) was on one level, Chester Cat is suppose to appear and say something but he didn't. But it was an easy fix of just restarting the chapter again and it wasn't too far into the chapter either. But keep in mind that the game is just old.

Overall, I highly recommend this game. I just didn't want to stop playing it honestly. And sometimes I find myself going back to the game and playing through a level or so. Still haven't found all the secrets and missing items though.

Pros:
-Amazing artwork and decent graphics for how old the game is.
-The characters aren't dull
-Not too easy and not too hard either. Everything in this game is pretty much a good balance
-There is a lot more to do in this game than just hacking and slashing, defeating bosses/waves of enemies, and cut scenes.

Cons:
-Can be a little buggy at times
-The story could have been a *little* more compelling

reviewText:
Fantastic game. I truly recommend it. Reminiscent of early games such as Psychonauts. Mini games resemble Little Big Planet. Dollhouse level reminds me of Saw and the Jigsaw doll.

The game starts to becomes a little buggy at the Oriental stage E.g. Alice's hands no longer grasps the chain when she pulls on them.

You begin to see repeats and less unique creatures. E.g. Ink Wasps are Bolterflys, Wasp Samurais move like Madcaps, Baby Doll dies to plain shooting.

PROS
1. Great visuals
The concept behind Wonderland is truly amazing. Looking at the floating Hatter Industries, the Insidious Ruins, the crying statue, hidden pathways that can only be seen with tiny vision and the vaiety of monsters to fight against each with their own method of killing.

2. Creativity
As above.

3. Combat system
Amazing. Each monster is killed in a different manner giving you the feeling of a unique creature. Unlike normal hack and slash games, you have to remember each monster's pattern of attack, else you won't be able to kill them. E.g. Insidious Ruin has to be blocked when he throws a fireball or knives, dodged when he charges and attacked from range. Eyepot has to be hit with a range attack first, followed by a melee slash. Repeat twice.

I was surprised to see that this game had such an amazing combat system. I was expecting a puzzle solving game instead. The dodge and block modes with the umbrella were fantastic.

The Hysteria mode will give the hack and slash fans the frenetic joy they relish if they prefer not to remember patterns of attack.

4. Storyline
Love the story. I'm at the beginning but I can't wait to find out more.  The story gets darker as it progresses, child sexual abuse, paedophilia, child molesters masquerading as doctors, p rostituted children hypnotised to forget and used to satisfy the perversions of wealthy London clients.

Steam censors the word P-R-O-S-T-I-T-U-T-E for some funny reason. Considering the type of content that they provide. It is most strange.

5. Movement
Love the double jump and the quick walking speed.

CONS
1. Movement
Jumping in the air is still a bit clunky especially using the air vents. Jumping in the middle of an air boost creates some problems for long distance jumping.

2. Character models
Other than Alice, most of the beginning character models (children in the hospital) are quite boring. You can see that they are repeated multiple times.

3. EA Account
I do not want to create another account just to play a game. It's irritating.

Suggestions
I would love to see the combat system put into an MMORPG. Hope EA and Spicy Horse Games can continue to work together on creating quality games like Alice.

reviewText:
At it's heart, Alice: Madness Returns is a 3D platformer, with occasional action sequences that oscillate between (light) third-person shooter and brawler. Madness Returns is a diamond in the rough. It would have been so wonderful with more polish and time to add new original features here and there!

I do not like brawlers nor third-person shooters, and yet I was able to enjoy the fights from Madness Returns. The first reason is that I gave a lot of thought to my key bindings so it feels as natural as possible despite the clunky design (it really requires too many inputs). The second reason is that the action is very tactical (at least in the higher difficulties, which I recommend) and has a great flow when the player masters the tools and weapons at use. For instance: Hit an enemy with the teapot canon to make it fall backwards and reveal its weak spot. Go in for a few slashes with the knife. Dash away to avoid another enemy trying to attack. Use the now reloaded teapot canon on that second enemy. Dash in to avoid the attack of the first enemy and quickly slash the downed second enemy. And so on. A ballet of butterflies and blades. New enemies here and there require different approaches, however the number of different enemy types is insufficient. Also, not enough true boss fights.

Where the game really shines is in the environments. Chinese ceramics, doll houses, flesh castles, mushroom forests, steampunk factories: grandiose, beautiful, oozing with character and magnificence. The dark undertones of some locations is really fascinating, and builds a heavy atmosphere despite the childhood themes. Platforming and exploring in such locations is a treat for the eyes. Alice can go as far as to quadruple-jump and slow down her fall, and the levels accommodate in consequence with aerial elegance. The gameplay of these sections feels good, and is rather permissive (even dying by falling to oblivion is of little to no consequence thanks to an instant respawn onto a nearby platform), so progress flows well and the game feels like an adventure and not an hindrance. Exploration is well done, and some little traps and puzzles can add some spice to the platforming. Problem is, the levels are really big and long, and some sections can overstay their welcome. Well just one in particular in my opinion, the ice world. I would have rather preferred that they make the levels shorter and instead include some cool new ideas that got scrapped during development, but ok, this is just me yearning for more. The reality of game development is not as pretty as this game. Still, there are some sections here and there that are completely different than the main game and add variety, like a shoot-them-up or a 2D platformer, but they feel very floaty.

Story-telling is not great, it feels quite disjointed. However the story itself is quite interesting, with lots of subtleties and darker themes. The person voicing Alice does a stellar job. Even though many people like them, I dislike the cutscenes that look like animated cardboard and would have preferred to see them done with the game engine.

There are different costumes for Alice, some were part of a pre-order DLC or something. Thankfully they can be unlocked, but it is by editing the Windows Registry. Seriously, how annoying! And also if I remember correctly it is required to create/have an EA account of some sort to launch the game for the first time, thankfully not Origin or anything to install. But seriously, how annoying again...

As a conclusion, Alice: Madness Returns is a game full of charm and character with grandiose levels to explore and a morbid undertone that builds a heavy atmosphere. Platforming and fighting is like a ballet once mastered, even if both will not please everyone: it can be argued that the platforming is too light and the fighting is clunky, and that both are repetitive. Alice is awesome, very elegant and pretty in all her dresses and movements, and she benefits from great voice acting.
Overall Madness Returns lacks some polish and could have been better, but still very memorable and enjoyable as is.
I liked this game so much that I finished it several times despite it being quite lengthy. I would only recommend it to people that are strongly attracted to its visuals and are not looking for state of the art game mechanics.

reviewText:
Intro
The game has a very creative art style that changes throughout the game with various visuals and great atmosphere.

Story
The story is very interesting and getting the memories throughout the game to unlock more of the story itself is clever. Not only that but you are able to go back and look at the memories any time from a nice and effectively organized menu. The memories are interesting because they flesh out the personalities of the people around the main character and your understanding and roles of those individuals.

Gameplay
The game also offers you some rpg elements like being able to customize your equipment and upgrade what you desire. The combat itself is very fast paced, with some slow motion moments that allow you to quickly hit your dodge button to avoid attacks.

Conclusion
Overall the gameplay is great and fun, and so are the puzzles and challenges that become more involved the further you explore the game.

reviewText:
This game is amazing.

It's not your traditional platformer, that's for sure.

Where should I start..? Probably with the best aspects of this game.

The thing (that I believe) that stands out the most is the design. The game itself is like a work of art - it's a visual treat along with the interesting soundtrack and atmosphere. All the level designs are unique and they change often, keeping the player immersed and curious about the environment they are in. Sure, there are some disturbing or incredibly creepy stuff lurking around all the time, but I think that is what seals the deal. Just. Wow. I've never taken more screenshots in my life.

Next would be the story. Now, I guess we don't really associate platformers with intriguing stories, but that's what makes AMR such a cohesive and linear game. As the player progresses through the story, he/she will realize why the levels are designed the way they are, why certain characters say certain things, etc. It'll all come together towards the end. Some people may think the story's a bit dramatic or just downright disturbing, but the purpose of the game is to uncover our protagonist's insanity and madness. It's GOING to be a bit provoking, at least.  But as for me, that's all the more reason to play this game.

Finally the gameplay is quite smooth. Platformers need smooth controls, and I've played the first parts of this game using my keyboard, but then switched to controller (when I twiddled around with the menu and figured out it's compatible with one - just personal preference). For both methods, I think it runs fairly smooth. I've encountered a couple of problems with some levels where I had to calm down and then retry getting accross somewhere, but that just might be my technical ability to cope with the difficulties of some platformers. The only issue I really have is that camera control is relatively important in fights, but focus mode totally disregards that.

The puzzles are also pretty fun, and there are different minigames scattered here and there. It's refreshing...

In conclusion I totally recommend this game. Maybe I should warn some people to not play this at night, but really, it's awesome!

reviewText:
I feel obligated to write a review after taking 18h 47m (according to the game itself) to complete the playthrough. (The 26 hours recorded by Steam of course includes time when the game was paused or sitting on the main menu while I had to be away from the computer.)

+ PROS

Great artistic style: The game is over-the-top beautiful. Even with the game's age you'd be hard put to find many others that hit the level of pure artistry in imagining the twisted vision of Wonderland.

Amazing level design: Each of the five story chapters (the sixth is only the final boss-fight and cut scenes) has a very different look and feel and are peppered with mini-games that break up the platformer main play with other kinds of puzzles.

Great voice acting: The actors were simply excellent even when the material was on the thin side.

+ MIDDLE GROUND

Flat story; As much as I was impressed with the voice talent and how well crafted the words were, the narrative itself was a bit ho-hum. And you get a lot of it by finding items that trigger memories (voice-overs). It's the same as finding audio-logs in BioShock but not as well executed because a lot of memories add only weak context to the story. It almost makes finding them not worth the time in some cases, but finding them is really part of the fun. Consider that BioShock Infinite takes just as long to complete on average as this game, but the Alice storyline has nowhere near the depth or detail.

Combat: It's OK. You get five weapons and all have important uses. In general combat helps break up the platformer experience of finding your way through Wonderland. But there's nothing terribly bad nor satisfying about it.

+ CONS

Too long: As beautiful as it all is, the chapters are about 25% longer than they really need to be. This made the fifth and final story chapter drag because I simply wanted the game to be over by that point. This wouldn't have been an issue if there was more to the story driving the game play.

Bugs: Clipping issues (getting stuck on a seemingly smooth path). Game locking up under heavy button-mashing requiring a reboot. Also the beginning of chapter three has horrible button lag that made it a chore to get through.

Clunky mechanics: The auto-target system locks the camera on the current target making you circle around it when moving Alice. This makes it impossible to rotate the cam to see what's coming up behind you in some cases. It also was a bit wonky changing targets. You can't play the game without auto-target though because the game often forces perspective shifts that make it impossible to aim like a traditional 3rd person shooter. You just deal with it as best you can.

No Steam achievements: Lots of unlockables are tracked in-game, however no one but you will ever know how many you got.

Rating: 6.5/10
Worth playing, just be prepared for a long haul if you intend to complete it. Replay value is very low.

reviewText:
If there ever was a competition to select the most bizarre, most grotesque video game I'm sure Alice Madness Returns would be in the top 3. Some of the art design employed by the game is simply the creepiest I have ever seen! But all this in the good sense as this is a damn fine game with jaw-dropping visuals and music that gives you the goosebumps.

This is a journey through vivid and dangerous dreams - Alice's Wonderland but as opposed to the cartoon this is now a horrified, alternative version of the same where the only way to survive is for Alice to be equipped with a bloody knife and a teapot that works like a grenade launcher.

I like how idyllic it all begins only to gradually get more and more corrupt and in the process Alice faces more and more dangerous creatures of the Ruin - this powerful force that tries to stop Alice. You fight throughout the game and you will do that a lot - but you will also solve puzzles and jump and also shrink so that hidden paths can be revealed for you to make progress.

You will jump a lot and many will result in your falling to certain death. But once you have put enough trial-and-error the game will be grateful as it shows you the progress Alice makes - a desperate progress to find out what caused the fire that killed his family at their home.

The game is pretty long and is full of hundreds of collectibles. I finished it in roughly 15 hours and got only 90% of the stuff scattered throughout Wonderland. There is a special menu called Troubled Visions in the main menu that is only unlocked if you collect every single bottle during each chapter. Pretty neat, huh? Plus, you can always try the New Game+ mode if you think Normal" does not offer a real challenge for you.

Buy this game and immerse yourself in this unique

reviewText:
IntroductionI bought this game on sale for $5 and it sat in my library for a couple weeks. After starting to play it, however, it quickly found a spot on my favorite games list. Even though some parts were tedious, the story kept me engaged untill the very end.
Prepare yourselves for an exceedingly long wall of text (go to the TL:DR if you wish to skip).
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=638015953
OverviewAlice: Madness Returns is a psychological horror game developed by Spicy Horse and published by Electronic Arts in 2011 for Windows, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360. It is the sequel to America Mcgheeâ€™s Alice, made in 2000.

Before I ramble on about everything that I enjoyed about this game, I would like to point out a few flaws with this version on steam.
First: the umbrella to block projectiles might not work (it didnâ€™t for me) and if so, you will have to change some files to get it to work right.

Next: the combat focus mechanic is far from perfect and has many flaws. It feels awkward to use at first and could use some polishing. Love it or hate it, this mechanic is essential for fighting certain monsters. I got used to it eventually, but it was hard starting out (because you have to hold down the CAPSLOCK key to stay focused).

You will also need an EA account for a brief activation (as far as I can remember) but then you donâ€™t need it for the rest of the game.

Now on to things I enjoy about Alice: Madness returns:
Varied environments: from dark castles, underwater cities, Victorian London, an asylum, and even a train. All of these settings make for an interesting experience as you travel throughout Aliceâ€™s now twisted version of wonderland.

Platforming: Satisfying and well designed (albeit repetitive) embodied by unique jumping mechanics (I will explain later). Something that would make the platforming better would be to include the edge grabbing mechanic originally shown in America Mcgheeâ€™s Alice.

Story: I wonâ€™t spoil it for you but here is a brief summary: Alice tries to piece together memories of the night that her family died in a fire and ultimately finds out who is truly behind her madnessâ€¦ The story is presented in an interesting way, mostly told by cut scenes, brief dialogue and memory shards that are hidden throughout the levels. The story is very thought-provoking and I recommend that you go into the game as blind as possible because of how captivating the story is, especially towards the very end.

Challenge rooms, puzzles, and game modes: There are several puzzles in environment, needing to be solved to more on (they can also be skipped). They vary from playing musical notes, finding blocks that need to be arranged to form a picture, and chess. I enjoyed most of them, but the finding the blocks for a picture is repeated around 6 times, which got repetitive. There are also multiple challenge rooms where the goal is to survive waves of enemies or complete a certain objective. When a challenge is completed, you are rewarded with some red paint. Each time you collect this paint, a part of a rose is filled in. Once you fill in a rose 4 times, you gain an extra rose container (like a heart). Lastly, there are a few game modes, each unique to its environment. An underwater side scrolling shooter, 2D platformer, and baby head rolling course (which is by far the most bizarre of them all).

Weapons: There are 4 of them, not including the clock work bomb which you will collect as you progress through the story. In order of appearance they are: Vorpal Blade, Pepper Grinder, Hobby Horse, and Teapot Cannon. (there is also an additional variant for each of these included in the unlockable DLC). The Vorpal blade is your first weapon and used for fast melee slashing. Next, The Pepper Grinder is used rapid, medium to long range assault (and for triggering switches). The Hobby Horse is a slow but powerful short range weapon that is effective against groups of enemies (and is my favorite). The last weapon you get is the Teapot Cannon, is long ranged weapon of high damage and large radius (can be used to break some walls).

Character customization: There are several outfits for Alice, her original outfit that changes depending on which environment you are in, a few others, and the DLC outfits. The DLC outfits and weapons each have buffs (or debuffs) that can fit your playstyle. Also, the Teeth you collect can be used to upgrade your base weapons, changing their look and empowering them.

Mechanics: many of them stood out to me, aside from the combat focus.
Shrinking: used to get through small keyholes and reveal hidden paths. Activated by holding down left control.
Health system represented by roses. You can regenerate health by picking up roses that enemies drop or finding a purple flower (if you shrink on top of a purple flower, it will regenerate your health). You can increase your health capacity by completing challenge rooms.
Hysteria (my favorite) where Alice taps into her insanity for several seconds to become invincible and gain increased damage. This can only be activated at extremely low health by pressing enter.
Jumping: you can jump 3(?) times in midair, losing height with each consecutive jump. If you jump and hold down space in midair, you will slowly float. Also, while we are talking about movement, you can dodge by pressing left shift.

Enemies: Small leech-like slimes to massively destructive blobs with baby faces and flamethrowers. Nuff said. Each monster has their own attack pattern and vulnerabilities, which you will need to recognize in order to be victorious. The enemies vary from environment to environment.

Level design: predominantly linear with multitudes of secret memories, bottles, and challenge rooms to be found. A few puzzles (mentioned above) are included, but the vast majority of each level relies on platforming. This may get repetitive, but this is up to personal opinion. Although there are no steam achievements (wish there were), you progress is recorded and you can see how many secrets you have found (no one but you can see).

Graphics/art style: Surprisingly stunning, detailed environments. One of the selling points for me. I was constantly taking screenshots and have 350 of them (200 uploaded). Half the time playing I was looking for the perfect place to take a screenshot (I got some pretty good ones).

Performance: Mouse sensitivity takes getting used to, controls are clunky at first, but after playing for an hour or so, youâ€™ll get used to it. The FPS and a few other things can be changed by editing some game files. You can find guides on how to do this if you look on the Community Hub.

Free DLC: Although it is not enabled by default, you can enable the DLC (that includes outfits and weapons) for free by changing the value of GIsSpecialPCEdition from FALSE to TRUE. Due to how much I liked this game, I decided to check out the earlier game, America Mcgheeâ€™s Alice. For a game made in 2000, it really impressed me. If you want to play Alice: Madness returns or have enjoyed playing it I strongly recommend you get a copy of America Mcgheeâ€™s Alice. It even has slightly better controls (sensitivity wise).

TL:DRTo summarize: Alice: Madness Returns features a unique atmosphere, impressive soundtrack (which I forgot to mention), surreal story, decent platforming, weapon appearance customization, interesting mechanics, linear level designs, vibrant and dark art style, and average performance.

On sale this is a must buy and at $20 I would still recommend it (if you understand some of the flaws).
For personal enjoyment Iâ€™m giving it a 9/10 and for review purposes, I give it a 8.5/10 because of its flaws. Just be prepared to troubleshoot any potential problems that could arise.

IMPORTANT ADVICE FOR  PLAYING THIS GAME WITHOUT LAG!

//Copy Paste from Steam Forums//  - Credits to Steam User http://steamcommunity.com/id/emikszjad


The game ran incredibly bad, like on every moment the game was locked between 20 and 30 fps.

What you must do in order to solve this:

1) Close the game (if you do this with the game opened, no changes will be applied)
2) Go to My Documents/My Games/AliceMadnessReturns/AliceGame/Config and open AliceEngine.ini
3) Search for this line:
MaxSmoothedFrameRate=31

This line sets the max frame rate to 30. Just change that value to 60.
MaxSmoothedFrameRate=60
4) Save and enjoy!

reviewText:
Bought this game then proceeded to spend three quarters of my waking hours over the next few days spelunking through the depths of Alice's insanity, the girl's got issues, to say the least. And after that dose of crazy, I've been having funky dreams, too. Been a while since a game drew me in this much. Consider this TL;DR.

Now onwards, to the good, the bad, and the ugly.

THE GOOD:
The aesthetics. The scenery is really satisfying and pretty, even when obviously bad things are happening. It changes slowly, sometimes subtly, but you can't help but notice how broken Alice's mind is once you scratch the surface. And the journey is going to be long, indeed. Things will get worse before they get better. Also Alice's dresses, they're lovely and fit the theme of whichever part of her mind she's currently in. Complete mood whiplash when you swap into the monochrome-with-red Hysteria mode that's one of the best visual depictions of psychotic episodes I've ever seen.

The combat. It flows nicely, and all enemies have their weak and strong spots. A few occasions will pit you against a formidable challenge, and split-second decisions will need to be made to survive. The weapons are imaginative and you can switch between them seamlessly, and Alice isn't shy about using them. The variety of enemies is decent, and all of them represent some mental problem Alice is dealing with. You also get a last stand mechanic, once you're down to your last rose, you can enter Hysteria mode (or Psycho Mode" as I like to call it) which renders you invincible and increases damage for a short while (while looking awesomely morbid and badass)

reviewText:
A beautiful 3D platformer (Don't rush through the levels, particularly the prologue and first level, stop and look around) that takes place after the events of American McGee's Alice. Alice, now older, returns to a corrupted wonderland to do battle with events from her childhood and her own insanity.

EA initially market this game as a psychological horror game. While it certainly is creepy and dark at times I would never call it scary. This game has more in common with games like Spiro and Banjo Kazooie than it does with your stereotypical psychological horror title.

The game is a lot of fun, both combat and platforming are incredibly satisfying (Having the ability to triple jump and glide from the beginning and LEARNING to master these abilities as opposed to unlocking them). Each area of the game grants access to new weapons, allows you to collect teeth (currency) to upgrade your weapons and gives Alice a new outfit whcih is a reflection of the level (a nice little touch). The game also contains 'memories' and other such collectables which allow you to unlock bonus content (concept art for example) which will appease the OCD side of the avid completionist.

The game does suffer from some optimisation issues (It's a console port) and certainly does control better with a gamepad. If you are considering giving this game some serious playtime I would really recommend getting access to a controller. After a while the game does start to feel stretched out, few new mechanics and concepts are introduced and it turns into a slight grind to the end.

Overall, I think this is definately worth buying and playing.

If you are still making up your mind, check out this Let's play by Just A Friend and Sinatrapod from the lparchive:

http://lparchive.org/Alice-Madness-Returns/

Happy gaming.

reviewText: I don't think there could have possibly been a better sequel to American McGee's Alice. It's darkly gorgeous and creative with brilliant level design and simplified combat driven by a dark, psychological story. That said, the boss fights were underwhelming to me, especially the final one (Just start the game on Hard or Nightmare), but all my complaints are minor. In contrast with the first game, there are few memorable music pieces, as there's much more focus on background ambience, though the addition of heart-pumping fight music is nice. Still a bit disappointing considering it's Chris Vrenna. Anyway, there are plenty of moments where I got stuck not knowing where to go - another leftover from the original, but this sequel really succeeds where it counts.\n\nThere's simply much more plot going on here, more characters and a mystery to unfold - all fueled by solid voice acting. There are some loose ends still untied once it's all over and I did feel some of the symbolism - especially with the end villain - was forced, but considering the dark creativity at display with the monsters and levels, I can easily forgive that. Seriously, the amount of detail put into places you won't even necessarily visit is amazing. Anyway, if you enjoyed the original game, absolutely play this - and vice versa. I didn't even like Madness Returns at first, but it won me over for all the above reasons.

reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns is a game like none other I have ever played. If you are a fan of Wonderland, then you will love the creepy, strange beauty of this game. Each chapter is rich with artistic detail that looks as if it has been pulled straight out of a Tim Burton movie. Every chapter has a unique look that will make you well acquainted with your screenshot key.

While the art style is clever and interesting, the level lengths are quite long and can be a little tedious after a while. Donâ€™t go into this game expecting a fast play through, especially if you plan on collecting everything.

The boss fights, are thankfully, unique to this game. They are challenging and had me at times wondering if I was actually playing a mini Dark Souls game instead. The clumsy controls make for an aggravating experience when facing enemies in flight, and donâ€™t even get me started on that umbrella.

Besides the games shortcomings, including a few bugs and glitches here and there, the game really does make you feel as if you were traversing through a strange, yet wonderful Wonderland. There are several challenging puzzle games spread out through the chapters that I felt were a nice break from the constant platform jumping, and the characters you meet along the way are interesting and unique.

My overall score for the game: 7/10. I would recommend this game for those who like challenging puzzles or those who just want to experience a darker version of Alice in Wonderland.

reviewText:
Do you like third person platformers?  You'll like this game.  You are born into the world with not only the ability to double jump, but you can quad-jump, and you can glide after each jump!  Platformers dream come true.

The imagery in the game is beautiful and twisted.  Some scenes are wonderfully gorgeous, while other scenes are ruthlessly violent.  I'm not really a screenshots kinda person, but I did end up taking a lot of screenshots of this game.  And the hair physics...you wouldn't think something so small as which way Alice's hair blows in the wind would be such a big deal but it is surprisingly pleasant to watch during those moments when I stop to smell the roses.

The platforming complexity is decent.  Hardcore types might be turned off because the path forward is relatively linear and the puzzles themselves are relatively straightforward, but it's still a satisfying experience.  Especially because this game has not frustrated me even once, which is surprisingly difficult for games in this genre.

The fighting isn't incredibly complex and the moveset is fairly limited, but it does give you four different weapons, fast melee, strong melee, fast ranged, strong ranged.  Some attacks work better than others against some enemies.  The fighting adds a nice break between platforming segments; I don't grumble when a fight starts, but I don't get all excited either.

For the completionist, there are lots of little things to look for that are hidden away.  I'm usually pretty thorough at searching for things and I've managed to miss two or three things in each level (out of about 30-40).  Fortunately, the game allows you to replay previous chapters you've beaten, so you can get a perfect score.

reviewText:
Alice Madness Returns is a great, well put together, 3rd person action game. First of all, you can clearly see from screenshots and videos that this game is a great looking one, sometimes even breathtaking. The game is divided into 6 chapters and each chapter has its own unique look and they all look great and I think the developers did a really good job in creating a Wonderland that is shaped out by Alice herself. Along with the corrupted Alice mind and the corrupted Wonderland the creatures that once lived there also became corrupted and even though I found the enemies to be really well designed at first, they quickly get repeated over and over throughout the entirety of the game but they still provide solid and enjoyable combat scenarios.

Alice Madness Returns tells you the story of how Alice thinks she's responsible for the fire that burned down her house and also killed her parents and sister. She gets the help of a doctor from an asylum which tries to make her forget about what happened and that it wasn't her fault. By thinking that she was responsible for the death of her family, her mind becomes corrupted, and so the Wonderland, and this is where the game takes place. Throughout the game you'll visit various regions of the Wonderland which have become corrupted and each one them has been designed in a very unique way.

Alice Madness Returns is pretty much a straight up linear third person action game with alot of platforming segments, puzzles, minigames and alikes. The game rewards exploration by giving you extra health and teeth, which you can use to upgrade your weapons (knife, hammer, pepper gun and tea cannon), not only you get small benefits by exploring but you'll also be able to collect memories". Memories are audio logs that when picked up they will trigger a memory of someone you know on the real world

Alice... Alice... Alice... I have to say i was very skeptical about getting this game, seeing that im not as big on Alice in wonderland than a lot of mainstream society. I jumped into it and found it to be a very smooth game with devilish humor and dark suggestive intents. This game fits me perfectly as for my studies in college and career wise. It plays on psychological themes in Alice's mind. Her memories, and within those memories a very dark and gritty atmosphere.

I have only just started this game and i feel i definitely got my money's worth and i plan on continuing this game. The graphics in this game.. although they're not amazing, they're clear, dark themed and her hair... my god, every strand of hair she has moves with her. They did quite amazing on the physics. This game not only captures a dark mind of a schizophrenic Alice, but involves a dark world with kind of a scary, horrific tendency to keep you compelled to keep playing.

The combat is actually fun, i actually really enjoyed it and it's difference on crouching and dodging. It involves her teleporting into butterflies and shifting around the enemies. The combat so far uses a knife that can upgrade. it's actually quite fitting for the type of game it is.

So i leave you with this, i recommend this game through and through and i'm not even done the story yet. When i do finish the story i will probably update this review even more but i just feel with this game it's too good to pass up. I just wish i had played the first one so i could understand everything. Enjoy this game.

reviewText:
This game revisits the fantastic and equally unique, Quake-Engine built, American McGee's Alice, and went under the radar as a rough diamond at the time of release mostly because of its rushed release schedule, and in part because of how different it was.
It's a relic of a better time in that it uses good old golden-era game design elements, like introducing you to new enemies every so often, teaching you how to use abilities and combat techniques, and then testing your skills with bosses and platforming sections. Some players will find frustration in these forced hold-backs and see them as restrictions, others will love the less forgiving gameplay.

Highlights
Exploring the world and discovering the, albeit thin, story and character history while passing through some stunning visuals is a real blast. I couldn't stop taking screenshots from start to finish and most of what makes this game so much damn fun to dig through comes from the diverse but always distinct and visually compelling art style.

* Interesting, worthwhile collectibles and extras which add to the replay value. For example, unlocking new dresses gives you different abilities.
* Some of the best visual elements and art styles of any game ever made, despite the now aging graphics and texture resolution.
* Lots of interesting new gameplay elements as you progress and weapon design of a somewhat different calibre.
* Old school Apply-What-You've-Learned boss battles and progresion.

Mistakes
Development for this title was rushed out by EA and it suffered as a result. Despite a number of small issues in different areas, it's a striking and alluring solidly built piece of awesome gaming which lets you to forgive its few mistakes.

* Invisible walls, when coupled with the, at times, unpredictable controls can cause frustration and take away from the gameplay.
* Mildly repetitive combat and lack of weapon variety despite the very interesting weapon designs are an oversight.
* There are annoying bugs and a general lack of polish in some areas, and some underlying technical issues.

Recommendations
Alice clocks in at an incredibly satisfying 13-15 hours of play time and even has lots replayability for completionists. It's fairly priced, currently at Â£14.99/9.99â‚¬/$19.99 it's cheapest by far from Europe. It goes on sale at -75% at least once per year on Steam, usually during the big sales and is well worth buying then.

* Like most EA games, Alice: Madness Returns includes a free CD Key which can be redeemed on your Origin account/client. To activate, right click Alice in your library menu and select View CD Key, then simply redeem that key from inside Origin as you would any other game.
* The DLC is included on Steam for free. It's hidden, but takes 60 seconds to activate. [Instructions to unlock the DLC are available here](https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=121133044)
* While fine with a keyboard, Alice handles better with a controller.

reviewText: I really enjoyed playing this game. My initial reaction was that it handles horribly, but once you actually get past the real world and into Wonderland the game really opens up and allows for excellent platforming and combat. The pinned down and awkwardly restricted feel of being in the real world serves to highlight how liberating going to Wonderland is for Alice, even if it has been overrun by horrible monsters. The story is dark and quite cleverly written, which really helps to drive the whole game along and keep you wanting to find out more (as if exploring the scenery and cutting up creepy slime-oozing dolls wasn't enough to keep you moving through Wonderland). Collecting memories as you explore your damaged mind helps to slowly reveal the entirety of the story in all its ugliness. Definitely worth a play; I would have to list this amongst my very favourite games such as Psychonauts and Second Sight. 10 out of 10, would psychoanalyse.

reviewText: Charming, twisted and beautiful; a 3D platformer set in a darkened, nightmare dreamscape of the Wonderland mythos. Aside from the theme, what sets Alice: Madness Returns apart from other 3D platformers? The answer here would be, without a doubt, the environments. The platforming itself isn't taxing, it's simply the mode through which we traverse the obscenely pretty level design; whether it be the Victorian, smokey and claustrophobic city; the pristine fantasy of Wonderland, contrasted very quickly with a horror-packed perverted version of; a dirty, mechanical Hatter's domain; or an underwater grotto. What of the gameplay? The platforming is fun, and whilst not difficult, it's not dull either, and is often spiced up with some combat - which, with a controller, feels fairly robust, isn't overwhelming and offers a satisfying break from platforming. The story, in collusion with the environments, delves into the sick mind of our mad Alice, spiralling downwards with a half-memory of burning her home, and in the process, killing her family. As is often hinted at, Alice is duelling with real-life turmoil manifesting itself through her fallen-from-grace Wonderland, and therein lies the key element of the game, the pivotal relationship between her unreconciled conscious and unconscious.\nAll in all, Alice: Madness Returns feels cohesive and well put together. The gameplay is solid, but the real reason to play is the journey you'll take.

reviewText:
Alice: The Madness returns is a game where the enjoyment of the gameplay and narrative may stand apart from eachother.
Let's start with the part that  ends up failing: Its platforming.

There is a distinction to be made between not challenging and boring or tedious. In this game's case, it is the latter when speaking of it's platforming element, the practise of jumping across platforms to reach your destination.

While the difficulty of the jumping puzzles does raise slightly, it rarely introduces new elements or methods of thinking that help you pass future puzzles. The gimmick remains simple. Jump platforms until you can no more, shrink yourself to see secret platforms or keyholes, and flick switches and shoot targets to progress further. The implementation of the latter two eventually ends up to be slightly confusing in the last chapter, but not excessively so.

This simply is a case of a gaming element that is it's weakest part, while being omnipresent. If the platforming wasnÂ´t basically the only method of transportation throughout the game, it couldÂ´ve been forgiveable. But right now it becomes a question of whether the game can be redeemed by it's strengths.

One thing that surely is not one of it's strengths is the combat. A lot of interest from this games comes from people having played the original American McGee's Alice. There, the platforming was somewhat reduced and combat took a much higher priority.

In Alice: Madness Returns, combat takes a little bit of a backseat. The grand array of weaponry has been replaced with your faithful old knife, a pepper grinder for a quick firing ranged weapon, a Hobby Horse as your heavy attack and a Teapot as a heavy bombardment firearm. Each of these are unlocked throughout the game, and do tend to play a part in progressing the platforming. But not in a Metroidvania style, of course. There's no level backtracking, which is good because that only helps one of the games strengths stand out: The design.

If there is one thing that the game developers did spot on, it was level design. In many levels, you feel like things have been hand placed. Every area feels unique, and are beautiful in their own respect. Seldom have I felt as enticed to just stop and look at the areas that I pass, as I have with this game. While I will not say that there have been some less interesting corridors, they are far and few between. All in all, the world does not just imply madness, it genuinely invites the player to believe that they are in a world of fantasy, where they can safely forget the rules of reality. And a play on reality this game really is, at least when going by it's story...

The story of Alice: Madness Returns is not the best I've ever experienced. In the end, it did not make me think deeply or differently about the things that I already knew in life. But it follows three storylines and beautifully merges them together at the right time. These storylines are mainly Alice in reality, dealing with events around her as she tries to manage menial tasks ; her investigation of why her 'Wonderland' is slowly falling to ruin ; and her placing pieces together of her past, the burning of her home and family that left her in this state to begin with. These three branches meet in the end and reveal the final plot, which wasn't very surprising, but very well orchestrated nonetheless.

Alice: Madness Returns is not very good as a game. But as a narrative story that allows some interaction, mainly serving progress, it can manage to suck you in and make you want to finish it. Which is the way that everyone should experience this game:
Play it once, enjoy and experience the story to it's fullest and end, and keep that experience with you. But probably not play it again.


Priced 10 at time of writing, a 50% off should certainly justify the purchase of this title.

Get this game if you are interested in a good story and are curious about American McGee's version of the Alice universe. Put the game on easy (there are no achievements to speak of) and try to muscle through the platforming, and you'll be rewarded with a worthy storyline, well narrated and voiced appropriately.

reviewText:
This is one of those divisive games, and one has to look no further than it's Metacritic page to find evidence: 75 among critics, 85 among players. It's certainly a weird one, so it earns both sides of the argument.

But here's whats up and why you should pick it up:

The combat is like the R rated version of Wind Waker and is oh so fun when it shines. I recommend playing on a harder dificulty to increase the visceral satisfaction. Switching between weapons is fluid and natural (Hobby Horse/Vorpal Blade combos are SO satisfying).

The atmoshpere is astonishing and unsettling in equal measure. The environments are gorgeous but there's always a sense that something isn't quite right, a sense magnified by the very sparse background music and ambient noise.

The weapon upgrade system is satisfying and gives a purpose to the collect-a-thon style gameplay.

And here's some nagging issues:

It's overstays it's welcome. Seriously, levels stretch on and on and there aren't enough world-specific mechanics to sustain interest. There are multiple times when one can't help but think alright
date: I get it. Can we move on now?". Spicy Horse could learn a thing or two from Nintendo's book on how to constantly surprise the player.\n\nThere are some shockingly bad textures in this game
recommended: which is so strange coming from a game with an otherwise very strong visual aesthetic. I understand it's an indie title
hoursPlayed: but more than a handful of other titles have proved that simply being an indie isn't an excuse.\n\nOverall it's an easy recommendation simply because there's not a lot else like it and if the darker aesthetic is something that appeals to you then you're in for a treat. Buy it and revel in the glory that is the Hobby-Horse."

reviewText:
[Full review of Alice: Madness Returns]

Graphics:
Not gonna lie, the graphics are not the strongest aspect of this game, so if that's your main focus then you may dissappointed. The graphics aren't necessarily bad though - just not the best. However, the art style is phenomenal. I mean I absolutely fell in love with the creepy environments and character designs. I even bought the art book for this game and have spent many hours going over the Timburton-esque style drawings. - 9/10

Audio:
Definitely the stongest aspect of the game for me. If you haven't listed to the soundtrack all the way, YOU NEED TO! Seriously, it's on Spotify, I listen to it al the time. It is unbelievably atmospheric, even just the title screen music is indescribably perfect for the tone of the game. - 10/10

Gameplay:
Okay, so this is where I stop praising the game. It's a bit of a button masher and one of those hack and slash types where the enemies NEVER stop coming even though you got bored of killing them like 5 hours ago. There are several different types of enemies (not too many or too few) that all have to be killed in specific ways. This would be fine if there were more varieties of weapons and/or upgrades for the weapons you already have. You basically end up using the same strategies throughout the entire game to defeat the same types of enemies and bosses are no exception. As for the platforming and puzzles; they're a'ight. - 6/10

Story:
I'm feeling pretty conflicted about the story because I liked certain aspects (like how dark and creepy both Alice's real life and Wonderland were) and I've always been a fan of the Alice in Wonderland story anyway. However, I was extremely confused about who the real villain was and what my ultimate purpose was throughout the entire game. Though you do find out who the real enemy was all along, I never felt like I fully understood the story even after I finished the game. However, I did enjoy the parts of the story that I understood. - 6/10

Replayability:
Unfortunately, I would have to say that Alice: Madness Returns has very little replayablility due to it's repetetive gameplay. Though the art style and soundtrack are nothing short of perfection, they can both be appreciated outside of the actual game. Combine the lackluster gameplay with the confusing story and I'm afraid there's not much incentive for a second playthough. Unless, of course, you enjoyed the combat mechanics. 4/10

Overall:
Though obviously not perfect, I do not regret my playthough of Alice: Madness Returns and would recommend it to any fan of the original game, American Mcgee's Alice. If you can get it on sale, it's a steal. - 7/10.

reviewText:
It's really good... yet flawed. The game is excessively linear and can feel a bit repetitive after the first chapters. There's a lot of platforming sections, and I really think you should use a controller to be more precise with your movements. Also unlocking the 30 fps cap helps a lot because it will obviously make the game feel a lot more responsive. You are also sometimes presented with puzzles and mini-games, but these tend to be very basic and fail to result interesting... some of the mini-games simply outstay their welcome. The combat is fast and feels good, thanks to interesting weapons and some creative enemies. Yet the camera does sometimes go nuts when you lock on targets, it gets stuck in the most unconvenient of angles.

Aside from solving puzzles, fighting stuff and jumping from platform to platform, the game doesn't really offer much more in terms of gameplay. It took me 12 hours to finish it on hard difficulty and I have to say I don't really feel like going for a second playthrough. I guess I could raise the difficulty to nightmare, find all the collectibles (they add details to the main story) and maybe change the voice acting to my native language but... 12 more hours are going to feel like a lot of time now that I know how the story unfolds.

The narrative and writing in this game is what really got me, I think it's pretty good. Many things are left unclear because Alice is costantly in a state of deep mental confusion, so that you are left with interpreting a lot of stuff on your own. Including the meaning of the ending sequence. The developers have revealed what you may call the canonical meaning for the ending of the game, but it doesn't really feel much of a payoff to me, so I am willing to simply reject it in favour of my own interpretation.

Another strong aspect in the game is the overall graphical design. Every chapter takes place in completely different landscapes, and all of them feel very inspired and sick. The screenshots in the store page don't really show you that much, but this is a game where Alice's mind is on the verge of complete and utter madness, so don't expect Wonderland to look all cute and safe. Even the real world sections are great and succeed in depicting industrial London as a grim, dirty and vicious place. The beginning of chapter 2 is the only part of the game which I didn't like from a graphical standpoint, but that section lasts merely half an hour.

Keep in mind that you will need to activate the game via an EA account before you can play it, and that buying it from Steam will NOT give you access to the DLC and to the original game American McGee's Alice... though it is possible to unlock the DLC by changing a single parameter in the same .ini file that you need to tweak in order to get rid of the fps cap.

To summarize, avoid the game if you don't like platforming. Do not expect any replay value unless you like hunting for collectibles. Use a controller, enjoy the writing and aesthetics and don't miss the train!

reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns, the sequel to American McGee's Alice, is an incredibly pretty game.

That's not the only similarity it has to its predecessor - on many levels it feels like a game lifted straight out of 2000. It belongs to the long abandoned genre of 'action adventure', a careful mix of platforming and combat sections on linear levels with just a faint hint of collect-a-thon. From the very beginning, it's worth adjusting your expectations to this.

Individually, the gameplay elements are.. well, solid. The platforming is accurate (a triple jump from the very start!), the combat is varied and allows for both melee 'bash them in the face' or ranged 'blow them up from afar' playstyles, and the minigames that show up are amusing interludes. The level design, as mentioned, is linear but once again solid with a hint system built into the very mechanics of the game for when you get lost.

A number of concessions are made to modern game design, for the better, and Spicy Horse should be commended for this. The minigames can be skipped if you don't like them, the difficulty can be adjusted on the fly, and picking up collectables is not needed to progress. Most importantly for me, when the you enter a section of a level the camera pans to where the exit/destination is - and then pans back showing you the route you need to take. This one change alone eliminates a lot of the frustrations I've had with other similar games. A good job was also done in making gameplay mechanics serve a function both in platforming and combat (for example bombs could be dropped in combat for damage/distraction, but also on pressure plates for platforming puzzles).

The game truly breaks its shackles of mediocrity and blandness in the art design and direction. The levels and areas are simply stunning, many set pieces are breathtaking, and it's clear that a lot of love and effort was put into this. Even when the level design doesn't hold up or gets repetitive, the look and feel of the levels continues to shift and hold your attention, not to mention the things added to 'hidden' areas that the average player might not even find. Moreover, enemy types are made unique to the areas (even if they have the same or similar attack patterns/moves). There truly is an atmosphere to the chapters, and indeed as you progress through the game it becomes ever more unnerving and unsettling. A lot of the atmosphere could be credited to the music as well. Whilst the original game had a much more 'active' soundtrack, this is more ambient and stays in the background, and it fits. As a spoiler, there is a level where you're slowly descending into the heart of a castle (literally) and the background track has the thump of a beating heart worked in, making the experience creeepier.

On top of all this, there is a plot that is beyond the average. Heavily foreshadowed and sometimes heavyhanded, it still left me feeling uncomfortable and disconcerted. In the interest of avoiding spoilers I won't give details, but suffice it to say that it won't leave you wondering if the game had a writer at all (as some games do).

For me, this game was right up my alley. My main complaint? The game, much like this review, overstays its welcome, and could have done with being cut down by even a few hours.

reviewText: One of the weirdest and probably the most creative game I've ever seen, this is pretty good, but it is not exactly phenomenal. It has great controls, great sound, awesome crazy graphics, interesting crazy enemies, awesome weapons, awesome combat, and gorgeous graphics. It is weird and â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ed up akin to the likes of a Nine Inch Nails video because lord knows Trent Reznor is a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing weirdo. It has great sound: on my 5.1 surround sound speakers it sounds great: the sledgehammer horse pounding into the ground makes my floor vibrate and the peppergrinder machinegun blasting shots off sounds like booming thunder. One of the coolest things about it are the weapons and how they act and look when you upgrade. You get a butcher knife, a hobby horse (like a sledgehammer), a pepper grinder (machinegun), and a boiling tea kettle (like a grenade launcher). Their graphic effects and attacks change as you level them up, becoming more and more cool looking. It is also pretty long, around 15-20 hours or so, which is a nice change because most dumbass SP games are barely over 8 hours anymore. The art design is amazing. It really is a great looking game. It's definitely worth its $20 price tag, and a must buy if you can catch it on sale. Also make sure you google how to easily remove the 30fps cap for a far more enjoyable smooth 60fps experience.

reviewText:
Flawed, but a very...interesting action/platformer/adventure/thing.

The setting and aesthetic and everything is downright amazing. The different levels are completely different and are all downright brilliant.

The story is...fairly interesting, if a little flat.

Gameplay varies between platformer and spectacle fighter; it's alright. The camera and auto-targeting have a habit of being painful (dodging into enemies or getting hit regardless). Nothing really special.

The major complaints are that it does drag on a bit (the levels could be, say, 25% shorter) and that the auto-targeting issues tend to be an annoyance after a while.

It's definitely a very unique game I'd recommend playing.

reviewText:
Madness Returns is an acceptable sequel to the fantastic Alice which was released so many years ago.

The dialogue in the game is as nonsensical as you'd expect it to be considering the source material and then putting this psychological twist to it where Wonderland is some how Alice's way of dealing with her problems.    It's a tad unfortunate that the game doesn't explore this more beyond just some short cut scenes and the even shorter collect-able memories" that you can retrieve.  Levels are usually too long and a bit boring also so if you miss one of these collect-ables it's not exactly enticing to go back and get them.

Speaking of the levels
date: at face value they seem pretty interesting.  The very beginning of the game has you start out in a lush green forest area with fungi and all sorts of vegetation.   This doesn't last long however as the game quickly gives you the impression that they got lazy.  This is because the level design is quite heavily invested in the platforming.  You'll come upon one area after another that's wide open and is littered with several tiny platforms that you must jump through.  None of it is very challenging and it just feels like it soaks up time.  There's not much to look at beyond the platforms either.  The sky boxes look nice
recommended: but that's almost all you'll be seeing for each area.  Unfortunately this is the bulk of the game and it doesn't take long for it to become dull as it feels like a chore.  Another thing that can make these areas last longer than they should is that there are often secret invisible platforms that often lead to the collect-ables.  These are found by pressing the LB button and making Alice shrink in size.  So frequently as you hop through areas you'll have to stop
hoursPlayed: shrink and visually scan your surroundings to make sure there's nothing you missed.  As stated before these collect-ables give you teeny tiny hints to the story.  So tiny in fact that most of them only last about 3-5 seconds.  It's not very rewarding and there's at least a hundred of them.\n\nI should also mention that there are small mini-game type sections within stages as well.  These are also quite boring and some of them seem slapped together at the last moment.  For example in one section the game changes up into a shoot 'em up style game where you control an under water ship shooting at skeleton fish.  It's not challenging

reviewText:
This is a very good sequel to the cult classic game, American Mcgee's Alice. with great graphics and artwork and really knows how to continue on from the first game.

Pros
+Unlike the first game were the platforming feels cumbersome. Madness Returns improved it with more fluid jump mechanics.

+Very lush, detailed graphics. Not to metion the various dresses Alice wears in each chapter.

+Unlike Alice where is it basic. Madness Returns adds a combat focus mechanic where you can lock on an specific enemy. Also Alice can do a dodge dash, and when low on health she can go in hysteria mode (Just don't too reckless).

+Inludes a new game plus for replayablity.

Cons
-The combat focus mechanic is a double edged sword. While it is a good mechanic. Its cumbersome to switch on multiple targets and you can't jump while in focus mode.

-Not as many weapons as in the first game.

-unlike in the first Alice where there are a fair number of boss fights. Madness returns only has one boss fight which feels cheap.

Some minor stuff
-No DLC in this version

reviewText:
Madness Returns is one of the best games I have played in a long time.  I do have a thing for Lewis Carrol's creation and by extension, American McGee's creations in Alice and Madness Returns.  The original Alice was okay, but Madness Returns simply takes off as far as sound design, graphic detail/design, and control.

It plays almost like a God of War game in terms of combat.  You have light, heavy, and ranged attacks.  The combat is fun and can be challenging.  It is a beautifully grotesque world created in the mind of a mad girl (alice) and the real" world is something straight out of Sweeney Todd.  There are light puzzling elements and a wonderful twisted wonderland to explore.

My only regret is that I didn't buy this game sooner."
