reviewText:
Would I recommend this game? Yes! 8/10

Alice: Madness Returns somehow manages to have colorful lands that are still dark, grey and a bit disturbing. The gameplay is a bit hack-and-slash, some shooter, and platforming. The voice acting is great; I love Alice's voice and the Queen of Heart's as well, and I love the Cheshire Cat's the most...so dark and yet a bit soothing.

Alice has a tendancy to be a bit snarky and doesn't respond so dramatically as many female game characters out there, which can be a good and a bad thing at times, but overall she is a well made character who comes across as rather lethal. Depending on te stage of the game her outfit will change which is a nice touch, and her animations are great; attacks fall one after the other without any clipping and move beautifully, dodging is quick and comes with a cool butterfly effect, and jumping and floating seems a bit elegant.

Cutscenes are interesting because they are done in a pen-and-ink 2d style that gives the game a book-like feel as it tells you a story about her insanity. They often give insite to her mental state and her past.

Most gameplay takes place in wonderland, but starts off in reality. The scenary changes with each location (and as mentioned before, so does her atire). In reality, the scenery is dark, dank and dreary, and the people of the towns don't exactly qualify for any beauty pagents. Despite their uglieness, their appearance adds to the atmosphere. When you first get to Wonderland though everything becomes colorful and vibrant...then slowly changes to dark, then darker, then even darker yet. Water turns to blood, vibrant green grass turns dead and ugly. Even in areas like the frozen landscapes has its own disturbing atmosphere with frozen animals that have exposed inards. Pleasant, right?

Each area of the game acts a platforming area where you have to run and jump from place to place, pull levers and turning things on and off. As you move around the game you are attacked by monsters and things, and these opponents can get monotonous as you are often attacked by the same things over and over at points. The enemies do differ frm level to level but there comes a point where you'd rather kill something else.

This game is well done, fun and disturbing. Some of the dialog is a little hard to follow, but its clever and dark and often strange, but remember she is insane and this is Alice in Wonderland (and we're not talking Disney). And as I've said, the voice acting is great so dialogs are enjoyable.

Alice: Madness Returns is well worht the money.

Ladies and gentlemen,

welcome to Ms. LiddellÂ´s magic land, Wonderland, where not all seems like it once were. A mysterious train shackels Wonderland and Alice tries to fÃ­nd out whatÂ´s behind it. One of the best platformers of the last decade. The PhysX in this game can run on medium to high even on a single GPU (I have a GTX 660 2GB), and also run well in CPU mode for AMD users with little to no sacrifice on the cool PhysX overall quality.

This Wonderland is not your typical 'safe for children' Wonderland. It's Alice in how a modern writer/director would of invisioned her, a crazy looney falling into states of trance that bring her to Wonderland, where she will confront her personal issues with reality in a not-so-realistic way.

Please do enjoy! It's worth the full asking price.

reviewText:
The biggest asset of this game is its visual style; it is breathtakingly gorgeous to look at. The environments are truly stunning, lending real depth to the tortured imaginings of a fragmented Wonderland. The story line is dark, engaging and entirely adult despite the youthful protagonist and fantastical thematics. It's twisted and downright brutal in places, and I particularly enjoyed the gothic stylings of the game.

However, having just completed this game, I'm actually quite disappointed, and it's hard to explain why. I should have really enjoyed this game as it's something that's normally right up my alley - beautiful graphics, interesting story, developed characters and relatively easy-to-learn gameplay that's just the right mix of gaming, cut scenes, puzzles and combat.

The major problem for me is that Alice: Madness Returns is actually much more fun to look at than it is to play. I could spend hours looking at the pretty graphics and backdrops but actually negotiating the levels got downright repetitive - if you like jumping from platform to platform then this is the game for you, because that's about 90% of the gameplay. It's fun at first with the triple-jump and float functions, rendered as they are with butterflies and graceful effects, but after a while you do get bored of doing the same thing over and over for five long chapters where the only thing that really changes is the scenery, and Alice's dress.

The combat style is pretty simple to learn but can be difficult to master - the odd target lock function leads to weird camera angles and can frustrate you when there are mutliple targets. Most battles end up being fairly frantic but the game does force you to think tactically when facing multiple foes, as you will need to employ different weapons to defeat certain enemies. To its credit, it's not the straightforward hack n' slash that I'd first anticipated. The enemies have a good range of abilities and tactics to counter, though it would be nice if there was a bit more variety in appearance - okay, doll's heads are creepy, but after a while you do become immune to the terror-inducing effects of black goo with an empty-eyed doll's head for a face. Adding more doll's heads does not make it creepier. Just harder to kill...

The game does suffer from a number of well-documented bugs, just check out the community hub, which solved 99% of the problems for me. These did not make the game unplayable but did detract a lot from the enjoyment and flow of the gameplay, particularly an inability to access one of the weapons for nearly all of the first chapter in my case without having to exit the game and/or reload from my last save point.

Another thing that I found incredibly irritating was the minigames - for some of them the switches in artwork/style/gameplay seemed a refreshing change at first, but then you realise it's just more jumping from platform to platform, just in a two-dimensional or other such different setting. On some of them the camera angles are so odd you end up having to work towards the camera with no clue as to where you're going or what you're supposed to be doing. Maybe that's the challenge!" you may cry - true enough

reviewText:
Alice: the Madness Returns

Background: Big fan of American Mcgee's Alice and Alice in Wonderland in general. Been excited to play this game for some time now.

Impressions: When you are dealing with a place called Wonderland you really need to give people a sense of wonder. A:TMR does some really interesting stuff with Lewis Carroll's base material and adds it's own twists that compliments the imagery established in the first game. In short it's dark, twisted and does everything right that Tim Burton's film got wrong.

The Good:
* The grim 'reality' of Victorian England is grotesquely exaggerated.
* Glorious and twisted Wonderland is the perfect counterpoint.
* Some absolutely gorgeous visuals, outfits and backdrops.
* Thoughtful plot with cues and callbacks if you pay attention.
* Honours the design, voices and locations of the original.
* Weapons have impact and look great.
* Voice acting is decent throughout, huge improvement over original.
* 24 hours plus game play.
* Shrink/Hint mechanic is fun and helpful.
* Very linear but lots of content keeps you wanting to progress.

The Bad:
* Lots of jumping puzzles, but few are particularly hard.
* Enemy lock-on makes encounters feel samey.
* Killing enemies is repetitive, use the same tactics over and over.
* Limited range of weapons and upgrades could have been more visual.
* Dark themes, visuals and language are not for everyone.
* Shrink mechanic could have been more diversely used.
* Hint mechanic can be too helpful.
* Hidden items rarely challenging to obtain.
* Retry system sometimes takes you back further than at other times.
* Side scrolling sections are unchallenging.
* Feels slightly 'console port' like but not overly so, plays well with keyboard

Recommended for: Fans of the first game. Those who like twisted and dark fairy-tales. The 15 age rating seems about right.

Conclusion.
8/10. Great fun to play and explore with some interesting encounters for those that like their fairytales with a hint of gothic about them.

reviewText:
A classic story such as Alice in Wonderland is a bold platform(er) to stand on; bolder still to instill such a dark flavored atmosphere.  â€œWhy?â€ you ask?  Because for many of us, our most recent memory of the character Alice is bleached Disney.  For me, there was a G rated nostalgia barrier I needed to break through to fully immerse myself in the experience.  Embracing the dark connotations that Alice: Madness Returns has to offer was effectively my rabbit hole.

The environments and overall feel for the gameplay pay a solid tribute to that N64 era of three dimensional platformers.  From hidden collectables to Aliceâ€™s environmentally adaptive dresses, the developerâ€™s attention to detail is apparent throughout. Further supplemented with artistic story-book-style cutscenes and well executed phasing to/from Aliceâ€™s mundane real world existence.  I found myself stopping to paint the rosses and taking an excess of screenshots.

I highly recommend this title to all platformer loving gamers.  9/10.

reviewText:
A twisted journey through the mind of a disturbed Alice
Beautiful platformer with decent mechanics and relaxing gameplay.

-----

âœ“ Great visuals and PhysX integration
âœ“ Levels are decently long
âœ“ Gorgeous outfits in every level
âœ“ Varied gameplay, it's more than just a plain platformer
âœ“ Delightful voice acting/cutscenes
âœ“ Upgradeable weapons
âœ“ A wide variety of difficulty modes

âœ— NO ACHIEVEMENTS!
âœ— REQUIRES EA/ORIGIN ACCOUNT FOR ACTIVATION!
âœ— Plenty of potato textures, poor graphic settings
âœ— Full of invisible walls
âœ— Even if you're using a controller, the game will keep showing mouse+keyboard commands
âœ— Although fun to find, collectibles feel kinda pointless
âœ— Capped at 30fps (see how to uncap below)
âœ— Nightmare difficulty is a disappointment (see detailed explanation below)

-----

Personal thoughts
If you're looking for a relaxing platformer game with third-person-shooter and hack-and-slash elements, don't think twice and get it. However, keep in mind that it has no achievements, which (in my opinion) takes away the sense of self-improvement for completionists. So you found all the memories/bottles, upgraded all the weapons and finished the game in nightmare difficulty? That's cute and all but it won't be engraved in your profile. Ever.

Looking for a challenge? Think twice, because Alice: Madness Returns might not be for you. Why? Because Nightmare difficulty is a disappointment (and boy am I gonna get thumbed down for saying this). It won't spawn more enemies, it won't give them more HP, puzzles won't be harder... and it won't take away the constant hand-holding factor in the game (clues everywhere and the Cheshire cat appearing out of nowhere, telling you exactly what to do).
Originally posted by you:		Well, what the hell does Nightmare difficulty change then?	The damage you take from enemies.

That's it.

That's all it does.

And given that there are no achievements, you're better off enjoying yourself, playing in whichever difficulty suits you best and finishing the game in a 100% solitary experience. However, if you can see past these major flaws, the game is quite an enjoyable experience that I'd recommend to anyone.

reviewText:
This game is awful. Let me start off by saying that I wanted to like it. I had wanted it for years and when I finally got it for a gift I was estatic because I've been wanting to play it for so long. The concept is beautiful, the horror atmosphere with the unique weapons and gothic take on Wonderland appealed to me more than anything. But then I played it on Nightmare mode.

I assumed through my vast experience in playing insanely difficult games that I could handle Nightmare mode (and 13 hours in I'm still convinced that anything lower would have been too easy) right off the bat. In playing Nightmare mode, as unforgivable as I expected it to be, I slowly grew to despise this game and can safely say that I will never purchase or play another Spicy Horse game after this.

Why is the game awful? Well, here's why:
1) Clipping - Clipping is usually something that's never an issue in video games. Usually the developer understands that it's better to underclip and make a few objects that a part of the terrain mere textures so that the area is easier to move through for the player and removes the problem of the terrain being an issue during combat, puzzles, anything at all really. In Alice: Madness Returns the clipping seems uber random and is the one of the most annoying things about the game. Every single texture is a part of a clipped object. Literally all of them. I'm sure there may be a few of textures that aren't clipped, but from what I've seen, every single thing is clipped. So what? Well, now, in the middle of fights you'll get randomly stuck on gravestones or in the middle of a shinking puzzle you'll get caught on the edge of an invisable platform and oops, because of that error you're either dead or at the beginning of the puzzle again.
2) Hitboxes and Colision - The hitboxes in this game are gigantic and the way hitboxes colide is infuriating. The hitbox for every attack is 100% garunteed to be larger than the animation for the attack, the hitbox of Alice is bigger than she is so the already large hitbox of the attack easily hits you unless you've made an awkwardly large amount of space between you and your oponent. The hitboxes of the enemies? Also overly sized. This means that while you're already getting caught on every single surface, you're also getting caught on every single stationary enemy. Lovely.
3) Checkpoints - I want to punch whoever decided where to place the checkpoints in this game in the face. Let's look at an example: In Chapter 3 once you get into Wonderland, you're faced with a large enemy as a part of learning how to use a new weapon you just obtained. reviewText:
NOTE: This is my opinions and thoughts of the game and not an overall view if the game for general audience. As with many reviews and opinions, take this with a grain of salt and do your own research. It is a shame I have to put up these notes telling people what they should already know on to do their own, but due to inflammatory commentry, I do.


Okay, so I wound up playing this game for 5 hours straight and absolutely love it. From the beginning, this game is artsy, gothic, surreal, creative, inventive, and a bit disturbing. The beloved fantasy realm Alice used as her escape from reality-from life-is thrown into chaos, mirroring the once innocent girl's now tomented mind. Through stunning and disturbing imagery we can see what Wonderland once was, what it has become, and what it is turning into. The camera and movement controls are just as perfect as directional buttons and a joystick, so those used to PS3 like myself had no problems adjusting. Gameplay is fluid, colors are vibrant to dull, sharp to blended, and the attention to detail is perfect. There is nothing boring or dull about this game as it really takes hold or your senses of sight and sound, keeping your brain stimulated and your reflexes ready.
My only complait about this game is that there is no camera sensitivity controls and during in-game play it's kind of fast, out of gameplay it's slow. Other than that this game is worth the money for more than just the gameplay, but the experience as well.

reviewText:
The sequel to 2000's American McGee's Alice.

Madness Returns brings the thirdperson-platformer to hack'n'slash territory, with fluid like combat, and easy to learn controls.

The games graphics are far more styilized compared to the first game. Sure this one is a decade ahead in terms of graphic capibility, but the overall style and tone is much more cartoonish, which I actually think aids the games narritive. The original was dark and depressing because that game was just that. A dark and depressing variation on the novel.

Here, the world of Wonderland is drastically more colorful. The combat is rather basic, but it's simple enough to not get in the way. This isn't a game that really needs combos. There are a few, and they do do more damage, but that's about it.

One of the negative aspects I feel of the game is that you only have 5 weapons. You have the Vorpal Blade, the classic Knife Alice used in the first game, the Hobbyborse, which acts as your strong attack that can break defenses, a timed Rabbit bomb which can press down weighted switches and deal explosive damage, a Pepper grinder that can be used as a longranged attack, a Tea-Pot cannon, which is a strong explosive ranged attack, and the last one is the Umbrella. The umbrella doesn't really count as a weapon, you just use it to deflect projectiles back at certian enemies.

Since the game has a hack'n'slash perspective, the limited arsenal is understandable, but can get a tad bland late in the game. The game is pretty â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing long. If it's your first time, you may spend well over 24+ hours on it depending on what difficulty you play on. And that's all just in one sit down, nevermind the amount of time you may put off on it. Part of this problem is that the chapters are so excessivley long. Chapter 1 took me around 3 1/2 hours the first time I played the game, simply because I wanted to explore everywhere.


The enviroments are absolutely breathtaking. The game runs on Unreal3, but they really took advantage of it. The Vale of Tears, The Hatter's Domain, Queensland, and Cardbridge are all stunning to look at. It's an absolutely gorgeous game and one that demands to be played at max settings.



American McGee is an amazingly creative individual, and shows that he can once again bring the magic back to Wonderland for a second romp. It's drasticly different combat mechanics may put off fans of the original, but as a sequel, it's absolutely fantastic, and I could recommend this to anyone. Even if you haven't played the first game.

Once tweaked effectively (i.e. kill PhysX) it plays smoothly and looks good on a moderately powered machine which is just as well as the environments are varied and all beautifully realised both in Wonderland and back in reality. reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns is an action platformer inspired by Alice in Wonderland. This is a follow up to American McGee's Alice, and shares the same style. That style is what this game has in spades. It stars the Alice in Wonderland characters, but in a very grimdark/steampunk universe. If that is your cup of tea, then this game is definitely for you. If not, then take a closer look at the gameplay to see if you would like this.

This game is a very linear action platformer. You will be ushered along from point A to B in mostly constrictive environments. Along the way, you will battle baddies with you selection of weapons (blade, hammer, pepper gun, umbrella) and look for collectibles. Collectible teeth can be saved to upgrade your weapons. The other collectibles have no noticeable effect apart from filling in some backstory. Combat can be quite exhilirating at times, since the enemies are varied and are thrown at you in different combinations. You will definitely have to use dodging, blocking and switching weapons to succeed. I mostly stuck with the Vorpal blade since it seemed to be the quickest, although some enemies require the Pepper gun to create openings. Learning enemy patterns is also very necessary to survive. The combat can also be very difficult at times, which would not normally be an issue, but if you die due to enemy attack you could be set back several minutes in progress. Checkpoints save automatically, but on more than one occasion I found that after dying I had to complete several sections of platforming just to get back to the battle. This can be quite annoying, especially since if you happen to fall during platforming you are usually just sent back to the platform you fell from. I do not know why they are different checkpoints for each, and I would much prefer just starting again from the beginning of the battle. The platforming controls are tight and fun, with double jumps and floating at your disposal. You know you made a mistake when you fall, and that is all you can ask for.

The graphics are definitely a selling point, especially if you are a fan of steampunk. Everything is heavily stylized, with only Alice having a hint of being realistic. There was some noticeable slowdown in certain areas, especially during battles. Framerate came to a stutter a few times, which is odd considering I can run most newer games from 2014 in medium-high settings and this game came out in 2011. The music and voice acting are all very well done. Once again, if you like Alice in Wonderland or steampunk you will probably really enjoy the dialogue, but if not, well it can be quite silly at times.

I would recommend Alice: Madness Returns to all those that are huge fans of action platforming, or like the idea of a steampunk Alice in Wonderland. While it is not the best of its genre, it is worthy of a try if you really like those types of games. I found myself not terribly interested in the story, but I am just not a fan of that style and i won't hold it against this game. People that are only mildly interested in platforming might want to look elsewhere first.

Grade: B-

Alice: Madness Returns presents the beautiful but dark memories of a young girl.

Pros: Graphics, Sound, Story
Cons: Controls, Gameplay, Performance

The world of Alice: Madness Returns is wonderfully crafted, each preserving a sense of eerie beauty.  The sound and voice acting is excellent, matching the world and characters well.  Alice's adventures through Wonderland allow her tragic and dark past to come to light.  A Mature rating is well-deserved.

The controls leave much to be desired, expecially camera and combat controls.  Though no support is listed, an XBox 360 controller seems to work and is recommended.  Gameplay becomes tedious after a while.  Finally, performance is severly lacking, with multiple crashes, bugs, and freezes.

Alice: Madness Returns, despite its problems, is one of the best games based on Lewis Carroll's classic.

8/10

reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns

To begin with, I highly recommend playing this game, and here's the reason why: Alice.

Based on American McGee's vision of Alice and her imaginary (for sure?) Wonderland, this game takes you on a adventure into depths of Alice's mind, which in it's current state, is a pretty devasted place. A:MR is a typical platforming slasher, similar to Devil May Cry but a little less complicated - combos are limited, there's not much special attacks etc. Fighting mechanism, though limited, is based on finding enemies' weaknesses and using them, which on higher difficulty levels (I played on Nightmare) can be a bit tricky to pull off. Throughout the game, you're able to use 5 types of weapons (with a very interesting design), given to you on various stages of gameplay.

Fights are extremely satisfying, challenging and well-balanced. The only aspect of fighting which I didn't like was targetting (by default set to Caps Lock), as it sometimes messes with the camera.

Platforming aspect of the game lacks a little comparing to similar games. There are a lot of invisible walls, meshes and textures which block your path (best example being straight floor with a little crack in it which you have to jump over) or places where you'd think you can jump to, but you can't. Also, Alice's ability to dodge mid-air, which makes your jump longer, sometimes doesn't work properly, making you dodge into the abyss rather than forward.

All of those though, become forgivable, when you take a look at scenery and level design. I've never seen world more beautiful and grotesque in a video game. There's always a challenge of some sort in your path, which makes the game enjoyable throughout the ~17 hours gameplay (on Nightmare difficulty). Every chapter is different, introducing new lands in Wonderland and what comes with it - new enemies.

The most important thing is the plot. Grotesque, fascinating and magical at the same time. I can only say that you must save Wonderland, to save yourself, and vice-versa.

Pros: gameplay, plot, atmosphere, fights, visuals, Alice and Wonderland

Cons: invisible walls (!), targeting during fights, places which you might find reachable in fact are not, a little bit of general bugginess"

All in all: 8/10"

reviewText: If you like Alice in Wonderland, macabre/horror, and gameplay that is simple but challenging, this is a great piece to play.  This takes you through American McGee's grim take on Alice's story.  This is actually a sequel to a previous game, but I played through and enjoyed without knowing that.  The artwork and dialogue/voice acting in this game are great.\n\nIn essence, it's like a 3D platformer with good story and art behind it.  The gameplay is essentially simple battles, simple puzzle-solving, and a ridiculous amount of platform-jumping.  The amount of platform jumping really frustrated me, but I had to just deal with it to see where the story ended.  There is a basic upgrade system and there is DLC available (embedded in the game files) if you'd like to replay the game differently, many of the extra outfits for Alice change up the gameplay well.

reviewText:
Alice : Madness Returns is a adventure/platformer game that takes you through various locations, while jumping, bouncing, exploring & killing monsters. I will keep the review simple, list of pros & cons below.

+Unique artstyle, creepy, eerie & dark is what it's best described as.
+Game runs fluid for me, 60+fps all the time (a few stutters do happen mainly when starting a new level or due to physx)
+Physx is amazing, dust, particle effects & other things all move around when touched.
+Various locations to explore, half the time you'll end up just gazing at the wonderfully done environments & backgrounds
+Platforming is actually fun and not tedious, you have the ability to double jump & hover.
+Cheshire the cat and his quotes
+Various enemies will be encountered along your adventure

+/- repetitive combat, while I didn't mind it others will be bored to death because you're mainly doing the same moves over & over. You do have some different weapons to take on enemies, the vorpal knife & hobby horse for light/heavy melee attacks, pepper grinder & teapot cannon for light/heavy ranged attacks and an umbrella for deflecting some ranged attacks back.
+/- Game takes about 9-11 hours average to complete, while I thought it was a decent length, it might overstay it's welcome to some

-Some ugly graphics up close
-Needed to edit a file to unlock framerate
-Previous game not included

Would definitely recommend this game to people who like Alice and/or adventure platforming games with a unique artstyle.

PC SPECS
GTX 980ti
4790K 4.4ghz
16GB DDR3 Ram

reviewText:
Alice Madness Returns is the successor to American McGee's Alice.

The Story is about Alice Liddell. She suffers from a trauma which effects hear reality.
She often goes into the Wonderland. She suffers from this because of a fire in her family house when she was young.
She lost her whole family to this fire and therefore suffers from the trauma. But something is different. Her Wonderland suffers from destruction and madness. In the game she figures out what really happened in the night of the fire.

Pinpoiting the game to 1 Genre is nearly impossible because it has so many different ones.
Jump & Run, Hack & Slay, Puzzle, 2D, 3D, Action, Fantasy, Horror.
I rarely seen a game with so many different influences. I really enjoyed it. The game got never tedious because of this great variety in gameplay. But the main aspect of the game is the Jump & Run and Hack & Slay gameplay. She has to pass several levels. To do so she has to jump and run, fight against monsters or solve riddles and puzzles. Or sometimes just explore the world. I really like the fighting system. Its really addicting for me because it has a learning curve. The game might be difficult to new players. I in fact died very very often when playing this game the first time. What helped me was a controller though. I dont think mouse and keyboard work well in this game. You have several weapons to attack the monsters like a blade or a pepper mill machine gun. You also have to dodge the attacks of the enemies either with an umbrella or just vanishing and appearing somewhere again. This game definitely needs skill! There are also many secrets and collectibles in the levels which are fun to explore and collect.

The whole game runs on the Unreal Engine 3 and it looks really beautiful!
I rarely seen such amazing designed worlds. Especially the PhysX effects give the game an own touch.
However, those can be quite taxing. Not even my GTX 970 could maintain 60FPS on High PhysX settings.
I only had like 5% of the game slowdowns or whatever so mostly it went totally fine.
Sadly the game suffers from some annoying stutter from time to time. Like all 5 minutes it hangs for a sec and then continues playing. This is not that bad and I got used to it. I dont know what exactly is causing it. Maybe the texture steaming system of the UE3 or PhysX or even EAs badly and horrible implemented copy protection.

Postive:
- Very nice and diverse gameplay
- Interesting Story
- Never gets tedious or boring
- Addicting fighting system with learning curve
- Beautiful designed worlds and artwork in general
- Stunning PhysX effects
- Nice and fitting soundtrack
- Nearly totally bugfree, even without any patches, since none have been released
- Limited Edition content can be activated with an easy ini edit
- Steam version automatically unlocks the game on EAs Origin aswell

Negative:
- Some small performance and stutter problems
- Annoying EA copy protection which needs an EA account
- The Steam version misses additional content like the American McGee's Alice HD version.
Check out my guide to obtain the HD version

Rating: 8.5/10

reviewText:
When I was just 12 I got my hands on this games predecessor, American McGee's Alice. Back in the day, it was well known for his beautiful graphics with a very nice horror vibe, a haunting soundtrack by Chris Vrenna and a great story. And these parts of Alice: Madness Returns as just as great as in its prequel.

The game continues the story of the alternative Alice we met in 2000. After the events in wonderland Alice is being released from the asylum and now lives in London under the care of Dr. Angus Bumby. She still suffers from her traumatic childhood memories and returns to Wonderland in search for comfort - but Wonderland once again changed accordingly to Aliceâ€™s psyche and a new threat to the whole land has risen.

Madness Returns plays very similar to that of its predecessor, as in most of game consists of the player exploring Wonderland, fighting enemies, and navigating the environments along the way. The game is a great platformer, giving Alice the abilities to double jump and float. To make her way through Wonderland, Alice has to locate switches to open doors or make a new path available. Other means of furthering her progress include shooting flying pig snorts with a pepper grinder, shrink herself to fit through small (key) holes and place and detonate the clockwork bomb.
Some obligatory minigames round the game up - though they are either interesting or annoying (mostly the latter).

The game is definitely fun. I personally enjoyed the ties to the old game, the way of telling the story through Alice memories she finds along the way that are filled with metaphors and hints to the events in Wonderland.
The gameplay can be repetitive, but is still enjoyable and fits into the nicely done levels and lore.

The game looks beautiful and has a very unique atmosphere that sucked me right in. Wonderland is interesting, though it could have been more lore-intensive. There aren't that many things to discover you wouldn't see in the main storyline.

Sadly, this game seems to be quite buggy. There are a variety of problems reported by the community, but most of them have an easy work-around.

All in all, I recommend to get this game on sale if you're interested in a unique story with a beautiful setting and if you're fan of platformers.

reviewText:
To fully understand Alice: Madness Returns, we must first examine the original game, American McGee's Alice. Which is arguably my favorite videogame of all time. Let's consider various qualities of the first title and let's see if they were brought back in the sequel
Alice had a wonderful level design and art direction, with impressive textures for its time. While Madness Returns retains such great artistic value and a fairly good level design, the textures and props scattered around are fairly repetitive, and rather muddy in some sections. To the point of low resolution
Alice's combat revolved around various weapons, saved for the late, very powerful, mandatory tools of destruction. Also, the title offered various enemies to keep things interesting. While Madness Returns got its good share of unique monsters, the combat is made a trivial affair by two or three weapons, with some of the Alice's moves barely being involved at all. It's a practical matter
Alice liked to throw in some puzzles from time to time, each of them different and increasingly difficult, to the point of reaching PLATFORM HELL in later levels. Madness Returns has a great total of three or four kinds of puzzle which are repeated every time is needed. Also, they are skippable with impunity
To cut this suggestion short, Alice: Madness Returns can be enjoyed for its intriguing, fridge horrorific story, atmosphere and artistic design, but it has very little to offer elsewhere, with a repetitive gameplay and a general lack of polish
... Also, no bosses.
... I belived I had to mention that.

reviewText:
Alice Madness Returns is the successor to American McGee's Alice.

The Story is about Alice Liddell. She suffers from a trauma which effects hear reality.
She often goes into the Wonderland. She suffers from this because of a fire in her family house when she was young.
She lost her whole family to this fire and therefore suffers from the trauma. But something is different. Her Wonderland suffers from destruction and madness. In the game she figures out what really happened in the night of the fire.

Pinpoiting the game to 1 Genre is nearly impossible because it has so many different ones.
Jump & Run, Hack & Slay, Puzzle, 2D, 3D, Action, Fantasy, Horror.
I rarely seen a game with so many different influences. I really enjoyed it. The game got never tedious because of this great variety in gameplay. But the main aspect of the game is the Jump & Run and Hack & Slay gameplay. She has to pass several levels. To do so she has to jump and run, fight against monsters or solve riddles and puzzles. Or sometimes just explore the world. I really like the fighting system. Its really addicting for me because it has a learning curve. The game might be difficult to new players. I in fact died very very often when playing this game the first time. What helped me was a controller though. I dont think mouse and keyboard work well in this game. You have several weapons to attack the monsters like a blade or a pepper mill machine gun. You also have to dodge the attacks of the enemies either with an umbrella or just vanishing and appearing somewhere again. This game definitely needs skill! There are also many secrets and collectibles in the levels which are fun to explore and collect.

The whole game runs on the Unreal Engine 3 and it looks really beautiful!
I rarely seen such amazing designed worlds. Especially the PhysX effects give the game an own touch.
However, those can be quite taxing. Not even my GTX 970 could maintain 60FPS on High PhysX settings.
I only had like 5% of the game slowdowns or whatever so mostly it went totally fine.
Sadly the game suffers from some annoying stutter from time to time. Like all 5 minutes it hangs for a sec and then continues playing. This is not that bad and I got used to it. I dont know what exactly is causing it. Maybe the texture steaming system of the UE3 or PhysX or even EAs badly and horrible implemented copy protection.

Postive:
- Very nice and diverse gameplay
- Interesting Story
- Never gets tedious or boring
- Addicting fighting system with learning curve
- Beautiful designed worlds and artwork in general
- Stunning PhysX effects
- Nice and fitting soundtrack
- Nearly totally bugfree, even without any patches, since none have been released
- Limited Edition content can be activated with an easy ini edit
- Steam version automatically unlocks the game on EAs Origin aswell

Negative:
- Some small performance and stutter problems
- Annoying EA copy protection which needs an EA account
- The Steam version misses additional content like the American McGee's Alice HD version.
Check out my guide to obtain the HD version

Rating: 8.5/10

reviewText:
Ah Alice, you wonderfully insane girl. True to the vein of Alice McGee's first game, this beautifully macabre depiction of a different Wonderland will have you slashing and bashing through six lengthy chapters. If you're looking for plenty of exploration and collecting then this gorgeously rendered title is right down your alley.

Pros:
-Gorgeous graphics which still hold up after five years
-Memorable characters and settings
-Gritty horror interchanges seamlessly with beautiful decors
-Challenging platforming and battles
-Long, rich gameplay with plenty to explore and collect
-Lots of three-dimensional movement freedom

Cons:
-Somewhat frustrating camera especially during combat
-Limited arsenal/upgrades
-Bit of a basic combat scheme, but very satisfying
-Very forgiving checkpoint system, might not appeal much to those looking for higher challenge
-Frame capped and a little unoptimized, might not run as smoothly on older machines (so I've heard)

The story comes with brilliantly simple and fun minigames that are all woven into the main experience in a way that makes sense but sometimes leaves one to wonder if they weren't pushing for too much, however, it all plays out nicely. I couldn't help but notice that some parts felt stitched in later on leading me to assume it got rushed at one point.

Every location feels like it's made with love and with an attention to detail, with a large and colorful variety of enemies to dispatch. A rich in-game collection makes up for the lack of achievements, and will most likely have you replay it a second time somewhere down the line.

All in all, Madness Returns is a big and beautiful, action-packed, sometimes frustrating but overall rewarding experience with a twisted story that combines both body and psychological horror which is bound to tickle your cravings for a solid action-adventure game.

reviewText:
I was only able to get halfway through the game before my data got wiped for whatever reason. I did want to finish the game, but I'm not interested in re-playing 40 hours worth of the game. This issue aside, it's perfect if you're interested in experiencing a new, creepy twist to Alice in Wonderland. It's primarily a puzzle game, but the 3D aesthetic, unique mobs, and challenges makes it more addicting than it seems. The game is pretty lengthy, but it's a great time waster, at least. There are a few minor bugs and glitches, but they aren't too bad to the point where they get in the way of the gameplay. While there are several other twisted versions of Alice in Wonderland out there, this is by far my favorite.

Music: 10/10. I noticed the tunes played for every arc fits the mood and situation perfectly. It tops off the twisted wonderland feeling.

Controls: 8/10. I used a controller to play, so I can't say much about keyboard controls, but I was able to get the hang of it without any issues. Some of the control settings aren't the most convenient, but they're doable.

Gameplay: 10/10. Puzzle games by themselves probably don't sound very appealing. However, this game is the full package. There's a well done story, the 3D aesthetics are well done, and the chacter, mob, and setting designs have clearly been thought out and pushed the limits of creepy. Despite this being a horror based game, you can see that subtle enchanting affect popping up here and there. There are tons of other small details about the game that I love, like the unusual weapons and outfits changes.

Graphics: 8/10. It looked a bit choppy and could use some smoothing out, but the creators did a great job in terms of visual affects. I couldn't pass by a new place without taking a screenshot because there was simply so much to look at and admire.

reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns is true homage to the Duck Tails type of games where you jump over obstacles, collect flashy stuff and kill enemies without graphical violence. I purchased it because the design looked so irresistable beautiful. And I didn't have to be disappointed. The world is awe-strickingly beautiful, crazy in the sense of fantasy and highly original. The running speed and jumping capabilities are really pushing the whole flow of the game and make Alice a sort of superhero. I played Borderlands 2 after Alice and I couldn't get rid of trying to attempt the double jump, that was so well embed in Madness Returns that I felt disabled from the lack of this feature in other games.

I consider gaming an escapist hobby and Alice: Madness Returns has taken hold of this idea and put it to use. Alice travels between two worlds: the real world, which is a dark, distorted, unpleasant and dirty place while the other, Wonderland is a colorful, bright, interesting place where Alice gains superpowers - a true escapist vision and understanding of balance between fantasy and reality. And it's yet another aspect that upgrades the game once you discover that the creators have thought about it.

Some negative aspects:
The game had an issue with the fighting script, especially when you were surrounded by several enemies. Executing the malee attack command caused Alice to either attack in the wrong direction or deliver several uncontrolled attacks. This put the player in a tight position because it's not a particularly easy game and every health bar was on count. This problem became more and more of an issue in the second half of the game.

Verdict:
The game was and Experience with a capital. It was fun, the flow of the game was very enjoyable, the puzzles were challenging, the fighting script has potential for improvement but overall the game has great replay value.

reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns is by far one of the best games I have ever played.

Alice is a strong female lead that although can do everything, she's still human. Struggling with her own mind you venture through her insanity and pick up the puzzle pieces together with her, figuring out what's really going on, what really happened. It felt refreshing and great to play as a young woman and I think many women will feel the same, she is fierce, witty and most of all, capable.

Not only is her world and mind extremely beautiful, you will find many allies and really enjoy the combat. The world is so visually stunning and well thought trough. Her world is lurking with secrets and absurd creatures, and it is up to you to figure all this crazy mindboggling stuff out.

If you're looking for a game were absurd and crazy comes into mind this is really the game for you. The combat is simple but yet very satisfying and easy to enjoy and learn. It is a casual game that's hard to not fall in love with. I enjoyed it a lot more than I thought I would.

Would absolutely reccomend this game.

reviewText:
... Please note that an Origin account is needed to register this game: if you already possess an existing account simply log in, otherwise you may need to create an account just for this game to run.

... Played American McGee's Alice way back when it was first out... Recently in the past few years, I replayed it and though it lacked in the graphics department, still delivered in gameplay, story and overall atmosphere... I would recommend playing it if you find the time.

... Alice: Madness Returns adopts the same atmosphere: gritty, dark, sinister and demented, even going as far to use similar art styles and level designs... While linear in gameplay, there are still the additions of secret and mini-puzzles that can be overlooked, and while combat only becomes a challenge on hard difficulty and up, you will most likely be dying from all the jumping and falling you will be doing... Yes, almost the entire game consists of navigational jumping and platforming, much like the first one... This in my opinion gives the game its charm and unique difficulty curve in today's games, as most tend to stay clear of this: to me it helps one to really stop and pace yourself, as well as look for alternatives methods of completing your goals.

... I touched briefly on the combat earlier, and the combat is very similar to most hack and slash games like DMC and Bayonetta, though a bit more washed down and lacking a rating system... The addition to actively dodge and time your attacks in a crowd works well, and the Hysteria berserker mode when health is low really helps keep the fighting fast and menacing.

... I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys the old game, as well as those who are looking for a decent length game with a moderate challenge, unique dialogue and an almost tangible darkness one can enjoy.

reviewText:
This game is like Alice in Wonderland mixed with Tim Burton (not like the movie) with a touch of creepy elements.  Read the game description for the detailed version of the synopsis.  Pretty much Alice has gone mad and can't let go of Wonderland.  If you thought Wonderland was crazy it's even crazier in this game.  The storyline and gameplay is really good.  The game design is excellent.  It has a mix of beautiful and dark environments, the enemies are cool and original (creatures not found in the Lewis Carroll story).  The gameplay is similar to the 3D Mario games and Tomb Raider games.  There's lots of parkour elements, puzzles, hidden items.  There's a storyline but the gameplay is mostly getting from A to B while jumping obstacles and fighting enemies.

My only complaint is that when you aquire a new weapon/skill the game gives you instructions on how to use it, which is fine, but instructions are always PC controls.  If you're playing with a controller you have to hope the game will tell you afterward what to do on the controller.  For example, when I aquired the umbrella the game gave me instructions on how to use it with keyboard controls but using the controller I had to press everything until I figured out how to use it. (Which is A while in focus mode).  Other than this I can't find anything wrong with the gameplay.

Pros:
Storyline
Graphics and art
Gameplay
Unique enemies
An even more twisted version of Wonderland

Cons:
Some on-screen control instructions are defaulted to PC controls.  If playing with a controller you sometimes have to press everything to figure out what the controls do.  On a good note though, all the basic controls are mapped in the options menu.

reviewText:
... Please note that an Origin account is needed to register this game: if you already possess an existing account simply log in, otherwise you may need to create an account just for this game to run.

... Played American McGee's Alice way back when it was first out... Recently in the past few years, I replayed it and though it lacked in the graphics department, still delivered in gameplay, story and overall atmosphere... I would recommend playing it if you find the time.

... Alice: Madness Returns adopts the same atmosphere: gritty, dark, sinister and demented, even going as far to use similar art styles and level designs... While linear in gameplay, there are still the additions of secret and mini-puzzles that can be overlooked, and while combat only becomes a challenge on hard difficulty and up, you will most likely be dying from all the jumping and falling you will be doing... Yes, almost the entire game consists of navigational jumping and platforming, much like the first one... This in my opinion gives the game its charm and unique difficulty curve in today's games, as most tend to stay clear of this: to me it helps one to really stop and pace yourself, as well as look for alternatives methods of completing your goals.

... I touched briefly on the combat earlier, and the combat is very similar to most hack and slash games like DMC and Bayonetta, though a bit more washed down and lacking a rating system... The addition to actively dodge and time your attacks in a crowd works well, and the Hysteria berserker mode when health is low really helps keep the fighting fast and menacing.

... I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys the old game, as well as those who are looking for a decent length game with a moderate challenge, unique dialogue and an almost tangible darkness one can enjoy.

reviewText: I waited for so long for this game to come out, and I wasn't the least bit disappointed. I've played the first game, but was happy to find that you really don't need to in order to fully understand what's going on in this one regardless. The level designs are beautiful and well thought out, but some of the jump puzzles are a real pain. I love how Alice's dress changes to suit the levels; it was a nice touch on a great game. The characters in the game are a well thought out twist on the characters from the books and the voice acting is *phenomenal*. Being a fan of the original books, I like how they've chosen to represent the characters and their respective lands.\nThere are a few things I don't care for, though. The controls can be clumsy and it makes it difficult when fighting hoards of enemies. Sometimes the weapons will lock up and not let me switch them out, as well.\nOverall it's a great game. I guess 'enchanting' would be a good word for it, since it's absolutely beautiful and has its own distinct personality. 9/10 I really recommend it.

reviewText: The game is a mix of things done very well and things done well enough to be just acceptable. The graphics and physics engines mesh well with the art style, yet the music is largely forgettable. The platforming is very well done, however the combat is lacking in some respects. Having read the original Alice books, the games make many references to the characters and events of the novels, yet is devoid entirely of all of the literary nonsense and madness, at least in the dialogue, that made the originals so intriguing. The story premise is also very interesting, yet the pacing and dialogue falls a tad short for me in the game.\n\nIt's a good sequel to the original, and people looking for a nice romp through a dark game will find it enjoyable, as will those who like 3D platformers. I still feel it could be better, and hopefully if a sequel comes out to this one day it will further improve upon the already solid series.

reviewText:
A gorgeous 3D platformer that will take you through beautiful and dark worlds in Alices mind, as she tries to deal with the psychological trama of loosing her family in a house fire.

------Summary at the Bottom------

Gameplay
Alice Madness Returns for the most part is a linear 3D platformer with basic elements of combat. The platforming feels tight and I never had any issue with the controls other than the camera in a couple of spots but adjusting the camera fixes it easy enough.

The combat is basic hack and slash combat with a small variety of weapons to use such as a teapot, a knife, a pole horse and an umbrella. Each weapon is used in its own unique way and is needed for certain situations both in combat and for progressing through levels. Each weapon works differently from one another, for example the knife is quick but does weak damage where as The horsepole is strong but slow.

Graphics
The graphics in this game are very well done with sort of a steampunk goth horror style. Whether it be the dark streets of london or the beautiful mushroom forests of wonderland, this game knows what it wants to be. Its beautiful eye candy when it needs to be and digustingly creepy when it needs to be. Each chapter is very unique with its own setting and visuals. The levels are cleverly designed using things that would be naturally found in the environment as part of the platforming, such as steam from pipes working as sort of a boost between platforms in the factory levels.

Character designs are unique and well done, with each chapter having its own unique characters, some being better than others. I personally enjoyed the mushroom forests and the card castle levels.

Audio
The Audio is decent with the voice acting being very hit or miss for some characters, however the voice they chose for Alice was a perfect fit. Not sure if it was the same voice actor from the first game as I never looked into it or not, but they sound similar. The level audio is well done and makes the levels feel living and tangible.

Story
The storyline is a dark one continued from the first game. However you do not need to play the first game to really enjoy this game, as I actually played through this one first without even knowing about the first game. I have since went back and played the first game and although it does help to understand the story slightly better, it is not needed.

You play as Alice who is a mental mess after her family dies in a house fire with alice being the only survivor. Events lead to Alice thinking she was the one who started it and blaming herself for the death of her family. This in turn does weird and disturbing things to wonderland, which is Alices sort of world in her head she can use to escape from reality. After noticing wonderland has gone into array and is in a very dark time, Alice sets off to find out wahts behind it and solve the issue and save wonderland as well as herself.

Summary
If you are a fan of steampunk/Gothic horror visuals then you will love the setting of this game. The storyline is pretty well done and will take you through a variety of different chapters, each very unique from one another and no you do not need to play the first game to understand this one, as I actually played this one first. The platforming controls feel tight and fluent, however the combat can feel a little bit stale with it basically being a hack and slash format. You have a small variety of upgradable weapons with Some being needed to take down certain enemies.

This is definetly a game I would recommend with fun platforming and so many unique worlds to go through and explore. There was so much eye candy in this game, I couldn't stop taking screenshots. The game is decently long at around 12+ hours nad a variety of hidden collectable items can keep you playing even longer. Worth it at full price.

reviewText:
Pros:

+Absolutely stunning art and world design.
+Alice is a very likeable protagonist (at least to me)
+Game is a decent length and is actually a bit of a challenge on the hardest difficulty.

Cons:

+Shaky performance on AMD here, I have a 6350 paired with a 2GB 7850 and I get nasty framerate drops every now and then when there are a lot of particles on the screen. This happens on both the Steam version and the Origin version, and did not improve with a cracked version of the game either.
+Relatively short experience
+Combat camera can be exceptionally clunky at times
+Boss fights are generally easy, even on the hardest difficulty.

Overall: 9.5/10, but sadly, as a huge fan of this game, the PC version suffers from slowdowns even on very high end computers (tested with a 4770k/GTX 980 and had the same issues.)

reviewText:
First of all ... yes, this game has bugs. I completely understand why that can take some off the fun out of playing Alice, but for me personally, this game was so much fun that by the end, I had all but forgotten about the bumpy start.
It's a lovely, intelligent story, combined with beautiful graphics and clever gameplay.
The design is wonderful to look at, although better in some levels than in others.

The game remained a challange right through the end. It's not insanely difficult, I'll admit that, but it's also not repetive and with frequent weapon updates and new enemies, you'll have a good time trying out all kinds of ways to kill your oponent.

It's still amongst my favorite games and (especially on sale) it's absolutely worth your money!

reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns  is a game that felt like a really clumsy dance with your high school crush. By which I mean you're constantly looking past the fact that she keeps treading on your toes, and at the end of the evening you're glad that you got to do it, but also kind of faintly let down.

So the game is interesting visually, with lots of colour, and the slow destruction of that vibrancy into a Tim Burton-esque Victorian London. I actually really enjoyed the black goo and the fire damage and the ebbing away of light, even if it was a little ham-handed in it's lack of subtlety.

The combat and platforming are fine - they're entirely servicable and combat in particular feels nice and responsive, but it's all very repetitive and nothing really interesting happens to shake things up. And, while the world seems large and entirely open, invisble fences artificially shoe-horn you along the plot.

My biggest issue - and it isn't really an issue, I just didn't really dig it - was the plot. The reveal is about as obvious as the screen in front of you, and yet it's teased so relentlessly. There's no real need to spoil it though, since you'll figure it out in the first 10 minutes of the game.

So yeah. It's a fun enough game, and definitely worth the price if you get it for a couple of pounds, but don't expect to fall in love - your bruised feet will be sore for a good couple of days.

reviewText:
This game is horrendous. Incredibly buggy, poor platforming design, the jumping must be so precise that it makes this game twice as long as it needs to be. You will die a TON if you are even slightly off with your timing. Tedious, my god is it tedious. This game is a chore, I'm so far into it at this point I'd like to just finish it, but every step of the way is incredibly painful and time consuming. I've played almost 16 hours and I'm only halfway through.

Pros:The game is very aesthetically pleasing and colorful. I've always really liked American McGee's take on the Alice in Wonderland tale.

The invisible platforms are a pretty neat idea.

Cons:Bug
Certain platforming areas I've likely spent half an hour on just to get across to the other side. In the section where you must free the souls in the Lost Souls Locker, some of the platforms will glitch out and get stuck at the bottom if you've failed and died too many times. Of course you don't want to redo the entire section so you must let yourself die some more until the platforms actually start working again.

Bug
The side scroller mini games are also terribly buggy. I use shrink to dodge some fire cannons and of course it gets stuck in shrink mode, meaning I cannot jump and therefore must start the entire mini game over again.

Bug
You must change your key bindings in the config file as well as going back and changing them in game. It doesn't recognize your changes if you only do it in game.

Bug
The cube puzzles only let me move one piece up or down. I cannot select any other piece surrounding the piece I just moved therefore making the puzzle impossible to complete.

Poor Game Design
Oh, you've just completed a really difficult part and then died soon after? Welp â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you because this game only auto saves (that's the best feature of the game btw). You must complete the entire section over again ( Í¡Â° ÍœÊ– Í¡Â°)

Poor Game Design
Whatever health you have is all the health you get when you are going into a boss battle. I was not warned that I would soon be fighting a Colossal Ruin so I didn't know that I needed to heal myself. I had 3 health going into battle and needless to say, died many times. Even when I died and restarted the battle it still did not give me any more health than what I had going in. Design flaw.

Poor Game Design
A very minor gripe I have is that when upgrading weapons it doesn't tell you exactly what is being upgraded. The weapon looks different but you aren't exactly sure if it does more damage, has a shorter cool down time, faster firing speed, etc. You just have to hope that it would upgrade all of those things Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯

If you're looking for a scary, thrilling game, this is not it. The enemies are more obnoxious and monotonous than scary.

I really wanted to enjoy this game, but it's horribly disappointing.

reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns is a rather unique beast of a game. I never found the jumping and fighting incredibly fun (Although it can be a little fun sometimes), the keyboard and mouse controls stink, the game has some optimization issues, sometimes the jumping is wonky as well as the game having frequent loading times. On top of that, the game runs at 30 fps unless you hop into the config files and change some stuff, which is a bit bothersome.

Despite these issues, it's still one of my favorite games I've played in a long time. The story, the view on Alice's mental state, and the presentation of this game make it all worth the trouble. Wonderland is a broken mess, and so is Alice in a lot of ways. Wonderland is falling apart and a destructive force is barrelling through the land, tearing everything apart and threatening to destroy Alice mentally. Meanwhile in Victorian London, Alice struggles with finding answers to her family's death in a fatal fire. Frequently, Alice slips between London and Wonderland, switching between trying to find answers from people she knows, and looking within her memories, respectively.

Weaved through all of these events is an odd mix of disturbing and beautiful environments that you'll be jumping through and fighting all sorts of nasty beasties in in your search for the truth. As the game goes on the environments become more gruesome, further signifying the slippery slope into madness.

Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys an interesting story and more interesting art. The platforming is alright, the combat is sometimes pretty fun, and the aesthetic is incredible. Just remember to look up how to unlock the framerate and use a controller.

reviewText:
Alice:Madness Returns is a terrific if flawed sequel to the original. As a narrative, it picks up the story where it left off in the first game and intelligently brings it to a conclusion. When it's over, you fully understand why Alice was driven to her madness in the first place, a reason much more sinister than simply that her family died in a fire years ago. The story is told wonderfully through excellent voice acting in recovered memories and in sequences cleverly done in cartoon cutouts. Alice also communicates with Cheshire Cat throughout the game in the game's 3D world.

Visually, Alice is beautiful and a treat for the eyes. The game uses a wide color palette based on the theme of the area she is in, and the level design and art direction are excellent and sometimes spectacular. London itself is appropriately dark and gritty, all done in greyscale, making the Wonderland segments pop more colorfully than they probably really are. Character models are also appropriately cartoony and slightly twisted. The musical score effectively evokes the mood of the game, though it lacks the disturbing discord that the original's soundtrack evoked.

The gameplay itself was mostly very enjoyable. The platforming was clever and challenging, and the combat (which there is a lot of) was very smooth (the focus" or auto-targetting system works wonderfully if used correctly). The game also breaks things up nicely with various themed puzzles and even some sidescrolling mini games that were very fun. While a bit long for a platformer

reviewerDisplayName: The Double Derivitive of YA MUM!
reviewText:
Hello close friends and strangers of the interwebs.
I recently picked up Alice: Madness Returns in a steam sale (Hell, I'll buy anything for $5) and finished it 23 seconds ago.
I felt like I had to write a review for this game because frankly, IT'S THE BEST THING I'VE EVER PLAYED!

The first thing that struck me getting into the game was the art style. It was simply amazing how bleak and uninteresting everything in reality looked and it's contrast with wonderland, which toyed with my own sanity. as close to everything tested the limits of my own comprehension abilities. I have to say, despite it's 2011 graphics, the style of art managed to almost blow me away with the occasional cutscÃ¨ne being artfully displayed as a puppet show portraying Alice's family's fiery death (charming, I know)

Now, after dedicating a paragraph alone to the art style, it's probably time to talk about something else. The storyline simply stunned me, making me unsure of what was real, what was relevant and what was a hallucination which kept me guessing until the very end where it made it blatantly clear that how many memories I failed to collect. With re-imagined, corrupted characters from a franchise which was a part of my childhood kept me interested as this game hacked at my innocence with a rusty axe, this game kept me enthralled for it's entirety.

Probably about time to talk about some gameplay. Now, whilst my heart belongs to open world games, I was surprised how much I enjoyed the lack of control I had over which missions my protagonist completed and it what order. It almost added to the sense of complete madness that was magnified by all aspects of this game. As for the level design, it almost felt like there were two parts to this game. The puzzle-platforming segment, which had Alice bouncing from mushroom to invisible platform to pressure pad, and the fighting segment, which had a interesting system of locking onto specific enemies and defeating them using different combinations of light and heavy melee attacks and ranged attacks which include a giant teapot-grenade launcher and a minigun that gives an entirely different definition to peppering your enemies (ADUHDUHDUH). Whilst the combat was comprised of simply mechanics, the creative enemies meant that you always had to be trying different things instead of spamming certain attacks.

Alright guys, I'm freaking tired of the emotional rollercoaster that this game provided me, i think it's time I wrapped this up. In conclusion (If you were going to read any of this review, this would be the part)

Art style: Sensational
Storyline: Sensational
Gameplay: Sensational

10/10 Would recommend.

Thanks for reading, I'm George, and I'll see you next time.

reviewText:
Edit: I felt this game deserved a proper review. The most important thing you need to know about Alice is that it is, at it's core, a platform game. If you hate those with a passion, then this game is going to really drive you...mad. You spend most of your time double-jumping/skirt gliding from one floaty thing to the next floaty thing. In between you will fight misshapen abominations with various kitchen gadgets and children's toys.

The combat is not really anything new, although I felt it was satisfying. The real appeal is in the twisted beauty of the levels. The devs really nailed it on it that front; Alice's wonderland is both whimsical and grotesque - a perfect backdrop for the convulsions of Alice's tortured conscience.

There's a part where you have to go through a tunnel opening that is, unmistakably, in a doll's butt.

10/10 would enter butt again.

reviewText:
Alice:Madness Returns is a terrific if flawed sequel to the original. As a narrative, it picks up the story where it left off in the first game and intelligently brings it to a conclusion. When it's over, you fully understand why Alice was driven to her madness in the first place, a reason much more sinister than simply that her family died in a fire years ago. The story is told wonderfully through excellent voice acting in recovered memories and in sequences cleverly done in cartoon cutouts. Alice also communicates with Cheshire Cat throughout the game in the game's 3D world.

Visually, Alice is beautiful and a treat for the eyes. The game uses a wide color palette based on the theme of the area she is in, and the level design and art direction are excellent and sometimes spectacular. London itself is appropriately dark and gritty, all done in greyscale, making the Wonderland segments pop more colorfully than they probably really are. Character models are also appropriately cartoony and slightly twisted. The musical score effectively evokes the mood of the game, though it lacks the disturbing discord that the original's soundtrack evoked.

The gameplay itself was mostly very enjoyable. The platforming was clever and challenging, and the combat (which there is a lot of) was very smooth (the focus" or auto-targetting system works wonderfully if used correctly). The game also breaks things up nicely with various themed puzzles and even some sidescrolling mini games that were very fun. While a bit long for a platformer

reviewText:
Alice In Wonderland by way of Tim Burton and Sam Raimi. You play Alice as her memories return and she has to come to term with what really happened to her family in a house fire and the reasons behind it.

Within the grimy Victorian seediness lies a fantastic platformer, and one of my all-time favourites, together with the orginal American McGee's Alice. The platforming is regularly interspersed with some surprisingly frenetic combat.

You have five weapons at your disposal: the Vorpal blade which is your standard weapon, the Pepper Grinder (read machine gun), the Teapot (read grenade launcher), and the Hobby Horse which is really a substitute for a Sledgehammer. Also the player can also drop clockwork bombs that either uses a timer, or can be manually detonated.

Though the fighting can get frantic at times, it is only ever really difficult if you don't employ some kind of tactics. The bomb, for instance, is essential for distracting enemies and overturning crabs to reveal their weak underbelly.

The graphics of this game are gorgeous, but they have an 'ugly beauty' about them, inspired by the East European puppet animations of Jan Svankmeyer and the Brothers Quay. The music of A: MR also has a disturbing charm, as it moves between whimsical piano and grungey industrial ambience.

I can really recommend Alice: Madness Returns to any platformer-lover, but with reservations about the adult themes that run through the game. Also, if activated (my Steam version was deactivated by default), the language can be quite mature at times, with the C-word used once or twice.

My only gripe with this game, and it's not the only game to be guilty of this, is doors shutting behind the player, thus closing off parts of a level without warning and without the player having fully explored an area. This often means completionists need to replay levels to get pickups they missed. Surely some warning that going through a doorway, or moving into an area, will end the level isn't too much to ask?

Apart from that, Alice: Madness Returns is a great old-school platformer with some of the most creatively inspiring environments I've ever seen in a game. Weapons are varied; Fighting frantic but fun; Lots of collectibles; Soundtrack is awesome.

Always been a big fan of this game: 9/10.

reviewText:
tl;dr Great atmosphere, good story, average gameplay. Good for a playthrough. Pick it up when it's on sale next.

By far, the most striking thing about the game is its art and atmosphere. Everything feels as off-kilter as a Wonderland run through a trauma filter should, from the dodo-powered machinery of the Hatter's hijacked tea factory to the utterly peaceful, yet utterly terrifying heights of Cardbridge. Each world is absolutely engrossing and sprinkled with details, making you wonder just what strange, horrible wonder is waiting around the corner. The music is suitably downbeat and chilling, picking up with heavy drums during combat, while the occasional string piece brings it all together with Victorian Gothic flair. The character designs are wonderfully macabre, with many returning characters receiving updated designs as befitting of Alice's vastly altered mindscape, and the voice acting is strong. Of particular note is Alice's ever-changing wardrobe; each dress aptly reflects the environment she is exploring, and each appears to have been designed with great care. Each dress also gains a unique gameplay modifier on a second playthrough, such as the Steamdress rewarding more Teeth (used to upgrade weapons) and Roses (the resident health item) from breakables or the Royal Suit limiting the health bar to four Roses.

The story itself is similarly strong, albeit flawed towards the end. About a year after Alice's release from Rutledge Asylum at the end of the first game, Alice has found herself under the care of one Dr. Angus Bumby, a psychiatrist helping her to forget her past trauma. However, all is not quite right in Wonderland as once thought, and she finds her world being besieged by the Infernal Train and the Ruin, monsters of oil and machinery. She must return to her once-again fractured world to find the source of the corruption, unravel the mystery of this new madness and save her mind once more. The trickle of clues throughout the levels strings the player along fairly nicely, however it feels as though a few too many important details are left as collectible memories rather than presented at key points in the story. My primary gripe with the plot, however, comes in the last two or so hours of the game. Quite a few sudden revelations happen all at once, especially during two key segments towards the end, and coupled with the fact that some of the clues leading to these revelations are, as mentioned before, left as collectibles that could be easily passed over, the reveals felt jarring.

Now for the game's primary issue: the gameplay itself. Now, the game isn't bad by any means. The platforming feels quite smooth, though at times shoddy camera angles can make some jumps harder than they would normally be. Largely, however, this is offset by the fairly generous and forgiving nature of the jump and glide abilities. Combat is relatively simple, with four primary weapons to choose from: the fast-but-weak Vorpal Blade and Pepper Grinder and the slow-but-strong Hobby Horse and Teapot Cannon. While fights can be a smidge on the easy side at times, stringing various combos with the different weapons, or landing a deflecting block with the Umbrella, is satisfying.  As a little personal plus, I liked that you couldn't acidentally dodge roll off of platforms; given the size of some of the platforms you fight on and how far you dodge, it would've been all too easy to launch yourself into the abyss if you could.

However, the gameplay is repetitive, repetitive, REPETITIVE. I'll admit, on my first playthrough, I really didn't notice it all that much; the atmosphere and plot were plenty engaging enough and I was so interested to see what was coming next that I really didn't pay it much mind. It wasn't until my second playthrough for a stream, and particularly it wasn't until I reached Tundraful and Deluded Depths, that I started to recognize the patterns of the levels: Platforming segment, pull some levers, a Shrink Sense here and a Clockwork Bomb there, combat, repeat. Occasionally, there are mini-games found in the different chapters, but some (the Off with her Head game, especially) become incredibly tedious. While there are hidden collectibles and Radula Rooms (challenges) to be found just slightly off the beaten path, they don't do much to break up the feeling of linearity. The Deluded Depths and Dollhouse levels, in particular, feel as though they drag on for days.

My biggest issue with the game, though, is that you can see just how much more American McGee and Spicy Horse wanted to do with the game. Missed opportunities are EVERYWHERE, with the most egregious being the lack of boss battles. Each chapter has perfect setups for end bosses, but in the end, they all quickly get handwaved away and you're shuffled off to the next bridging London segment with no real payoff. A lot of features found in the beta trailer, like the expanded London segments and the ability to swim through the Deluded Depths, would've been more than welcome, the London segments especially; London would've felt more like a proper setting in its own right than as simply a bridge between Wonderland visits.

In the end, though, I can't say I didn't have fun with the game, and its art and atmosphere are truly wonderful to experience. It's a shame that the gameplay doesn't quite reach the same quality, but it's by no means a bad game; it's just not really one you'll want to play through more than once. If you're looking for an aesthetically-rich world and don't mind the gameplay being just alright, give it a look.
