reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns is a 3D on-rails platformer with horror elements that tells the story of Alice Liddell - a teenaged girl who's suffering from trauma caused by the death of her family in a fire. The player's role is to guide her through the Wonderland, which represents different parts of her mind, to recover her lost memory and find the source of corruption that's been ruining it.

In terms of graphics, I wouldn't compliment their general quality as the models and textures aren't top notch, but the general design is splendid. The locations are beautifully done, dark and moody, which creates an incredible effect when combined with the game's psychodelic music. It all creates a borderline horror-like climate throughout most of the game. The imagery may not be as disturbing as for example Yume Nikki, but comes quite close.

In terms of gameplay, the player has quite a bit of movement options in his hands, and even more when it comes to combat. Alice can quadrupple jump and float, making her one of the more nimble characters in the history of platformers. She also gets an assortment of different (upgradeable) weapons that she can use to battle the quite diverse library of foes she will encounter, as well as a dodge move which is basically a flash step. She can also lock-on to her enemies and aim automatically. This all makes the combat very satisfying and when you lose, it's usually your own fault, not the control's. For those who feel hardcore enough, there is the Nightmare difficulty which vastly bumps up the strength of enemies, and certain dresses Alice can wear albo make the game harder (like limiting her health). Of course, you can also opt for a low difficulty, if you're a casual gamer. Pretty much the only bad thing is the fact that the final boss is kind of easy in comparison to the rest of the game on any given difficulty.

One last thing to say is that this game is not for kids. More thanks to disturbing imagery than anything, really.

Overall, this game is a great platformer, with moody, psychodelic environments and very good combat system. I recommend it to both casual players and hardcore on-rails platformer fans.

reviewText:
8.6/10
A very flawed but a gem of a game, which really should have cut some content here and there to give more time to polish.

Wonderland is falling apart, Alice forgot what happened to her family. Why is Alice going mad, what happened to her family and what happens in the real world when Alice is in Wonderland, find it out while playing this deep and crazy and mad game!

+ Great deep storyline when you make it past the halfway point
+ Great graphics most of the time
+ Great platforming gameplay
+ NVIDIA physx looks beautiful!
- Framedrops and stutters every now and then!!!
- Story starts slowly
- Boring and flawed start of the game
- Not always great graphics
- Terrible voiceover sometimes
- Requires some fiddling with .ini files to get 60 or higher fps
- Had to noclip one level due to a bug (which also required fiddling with .ini files to enable it)

The game starts ok, graphics ok and the story is very vage. But halfway, after 6 to 8 hours the game really starts to shine, the bad voiceovers dissapear, graphics become more beatifull every level, story starts to become really interesting etc. The story even becomes pretty gross and suddenly all the madness slowly gets explained by mixing real world and immaginary wonderland world experiences. The game really is great, but sadly it takes a while for it to show it. And no the last few chapters aren't perfect either, but the story really excells here and you discover more and more the further you play.

I recommend playing this game if you like platformers and games with a pretty hefty storyline, since it definately is not a children game. And if you find yourself being bored, expecially the first (and longest) chapter please try to make it through. Its a great game when you allow yourself to look deep enough since the lack of polish here and there really tries to kick you out.

reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns... My favourite game since its prequel, American Mcgee's Alice, Which by the way, isn't on Steam OR Origin. I tried finding it...

It's one hell of a beautiful game, I must say. The visuals are meant to be taken as metaphors most of the time, so to those who don't like things like that... This game won't be your cup of Tea. It will be a really weird game to you.

The game DOES have peculiarities and it's just how it's meant to be. I like the story. Alice is one hell of a role model. Except the brutality in Wonderland part. She's a character that I could describe as one of the most humane characters in the whole gaming industry. She's smart, but not strong or too fragile, she's not some kind of an all-knowing person. She has her fears, doubts, strengths, weaknesses. She's a beliavable character.

I know the game has its plot holes, but so does nearly every game EVER.

Now, gameplay-wise, I would advise anyone who has a PC-compatible controller to try and play it. It feels way smoother that way. I'm not saying the PC controls don't work or anything(Which has happened to me sometimes), but the game is smoother when played with a controller.

There are some sections of this game that should have ended sooner. They felt dragged out and I know they would be. That's what you get when you work with EA in the first place. There is no way to get rid of tutorials even after you have completed the game, so it will remind you again and again about some stuff.

Overall, the game has its flaws, but it still stands up strong. DEFINITELY recommended.

EDIT: Forgot to mention that the music is very appropriate in most cases, but it's just not as memorable as the one from American Mcgee's Alice.

It is the similar fantastic psychological horror. action-adventure, third person video game as the first one, however, you do not need to play the first one in order to enjoy this game as it isnt a direct sequal. reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns is a third person psychological horror action shooter and adventure game, developed by Spicy Horse and is a sequel to the American McGee's Alice game from 2000.
In this game you play as Alice Lidell, a girl who mentally suffers from a trauma which is caused by the death of her family.
Alice was discharged from the pschiatric clinic and since then she lives in an orphanage that houses mentally traumatized orphans.

In the game Alice tries to get rid of her trauma,learns about her past, the truth behind it and and wakes up in Wonderland that is corrupted by an evil force.
The story is told by animated drawings scenes, in-game cinematics and in-game documents.

Throughout the game Alice hops between the real-world and locations in Wonderland.
Alice is occasionally guided by a weird Cat with riddles and hints.
Once in Wonderland Alice gains weapons to defend herself from the evil forces.
Every monstrosity slain gives Alice teeth to upgrade her weapons and roses to refill her health bar.
Almost every level has many things to search for such as secret chambers, memories, bottles, teeth, puzzles, pig snouts etc.
Almost the entire game you run, jump and dodge and attack to make progress through the story.


Alice: Madness Returns is a game with many ingredients and not easy to label, this makes the game hard to label itself.
If you are looking for a wonderful fairylike horror game with magnificent narrating and a high amount of gameplay length, perhaps this game might be something for you!

reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns took me down the rabbit hole like no other could. I love this version of Alice in Wonderland. It might have caused me to question my own sanity but I wouldn't have it any other way.

Practical info:
At first I couldn't play the game as I was supposed to play it because I couldn't use the umbrella. It has been confirmed by a lot of people that the game doesn't always want to be played. I tried playing further by using the trick with the rabbitbomb but it was tiresome. I needed a real solution. Buying an xbox-controller for the pc was that solution (in my case).

Experience:
+ Art: simply beautiful! I played it on a big tv and it was as if my tv turned into a painting!
+ Story: Halucinating instead of dreaming. Purrrfect!
+ Gameplay: the concept is rather simple. Platforming and battling. The battle style is a bit comparable to the legend of Zelda. (Don't expect a legend of Zelda wannabee though! The games are not similar, I was simply talking about the battling system.) For me it sometimes felt a bit repetitive.
+ Puzzles: too simple! It could have taken this a step further but it didn't. It was a bit disappointing.

Overall score:
I don't like to put a number on a game but I'll tell you why I liked the game. I liked playing it because it was equally beautiful as it was a t(h)reat to my (in)sanity. But if I need to be honest with myself it feels like the art and the story need to compensate for the gameplay and the puzzles. Even though it was enjoyable, it sometimes felt a bit repetitive and the puzzles were a bit simple. In the end I'm glad I bought the game.

(If you really want a number, take 7/10)

reviewText: This is a good game, that is plagued by bugs and errors, mainly caused by EA's DRM. First off, why does EA need DRM on an offline single-player game? Second, since it's published by EA, there's no cloud saving via steam. And on Origin, cloud saving doesn't work at all. I've lost my save file twice because of this. If you like platforming games with puzzle thrown-in, I definitely recommend it. When it DOES work, the game is fun. Controls are smooth, combat is similar to Legend of Zelda with it's targeting system, you upgrade your weapons by collecting teeth(similar to the red orbs from the God of War games). I recommend getting the game, but you're probably better off buying it on xbox360 or PS3; those versions might have fewer bugs.

reviewText:
It's an alright game, 6/10 maybe. The story is good, albeit very dark.

The reason I don't recommend this is that this game is mainly repetition. Chapters are insanely long of platforming. The game was charming for the first 3-4 hours, by after that, it becomes tedious. Chapter 5 in particular, is ridiculously long. 2 hours of no story-telling and simply jumping and jumping and jumping until you finally get the story bit.

It's as if they tried to make us go as mad as alice.

reviewText:
A good linear RPG with combat similar to the Zelda games.  Combat isn't as good, nor is it open world, and not nearly as many weapons although there are multiple upgradeable weapon choices for both ranged and melee, and you can toggle ranged weapons while they are on their respective short cooldowns.  The graphics aren't terrible or great, but the atmosphere is wonderfull and the art is fantastic.  I'm just under 10 hours in and a little under halfway through so it seems like the game will be decent length if you don't blow through it.

9/10

Pros

Enough weapons to keep combat interesting
Art/scenary is fantastic
Collectibles to find
Plenty of secret places(not always so secret)
Quadruple jump-Makes the platforming easier if you have issues with that
Floating-See above

Cons

Linear
Most of the combat isn't too hard but some fights I found wayyy too hard for how the rest of the game is
Game can be pretty forgiving usually, if you die you respawn close, not always the case and some parts you mess up a jump by an inch and youre going back pretty far just to fail again.


TL;DR If you were already interested and would like a linear somewhat zelda combatlike RPG worth the 20 bucks easily, and at the very least pick it up on sale.  I can see myself replaying this again, not right away, but Im not uninstalling and putting it down for good.  I dig the art too much!

reviewText:
It's okay but wasn't as fun as I had hoped. It has some nice ideas but is too lengthy with too little variety and bored me throughout numerous parts.

It lacks difficulty and challenge and playing it can feel like a tedious chore. I got used to the looks of each level quickly. You change between reality and Wonderland scenes in a predictable succession. They can appear initially impressive but everything submits heavily to the basic mechanics. There isn't much feeling of consistency or meaning, the levels are cluttered and lack elements to excite you with. One could end in a minute and the other in hours and it would still amount to the same. Sometimes while platforming you change without too much of a warning between various graphical dimensions and visual styles or even have the game turn into a sidescrolling shooter. Some of these sections fit the themes of the levels they happen in nicely and were interesting to witness but gameplay-wise turned repetitive soon.

You hardly ever interact with anyone or anything that isn't a mob to slash at but move on and on traversing the always kinda same ways and exploring the kinda same secret passages to unlock collectibles you might care or not about. Having a deranged protagonist explore her mind to sort things out regarding her psyche, her real-life situation and that Wonderland of hers could've offered lots of possibilites to deal with your environments and their inhabitants, and the interim" scenes of switching worlds were rather interesting but the game dares not to progress beyond it's otherwise predictable level patterns and fundamental platforming and combat mechanics which leaves the rather nice voice actors severly underused as well.

There isn't much substance to the characters. They aren't very tangible
date: they don't have too many lines and when they speak they do it in ways or making references to previous events or characters that can be hard to understand (without being necessarily complicated by nature) for non-native English speakers or when not knowing the book this is based on or the previous game "American McGeeâ€™s Alice". There isn't too much of story progression. You're jumping and slashing your way through the mind of Alice

reviewText:
I played a lot of this before Steam introduced it's game time logging feature.

A very somber and melancholy game. A neat art direction though, some of the character designs are funky, and I particularly like Alices model, and how her hair, dress and ribbons blow in the wind when you're standing idle or moving around. Her boots give me the biggest boner.

The voice acting has bouts of god like vocalisations, and then some really iffy and forced lines that aren't delivered properly. For example, when you're interacting with the children in the home at the very start of the game after the opening cut-scene. Some of Alices' responces to the children feel very wooden and fall flat. I'm not sure if this is bad VA-ing, writing or just because Alice is meant to be completely insane.

Level design is linear with a few branches off here and there for hidden areas that don't really offer you anything except clues into the back story of the game and sub characters. Its not very hard either, hard mode is quite easy. The gameplay isn't very engaging either.

After having played a good few hours if find that this game would have been better suited to a movie adaptation rather than a game. It's really boring to play and it feels like real a chore. Everything is the same. Jump here, jump there, shoot this thing that opens that thing, fight the same enemy you've been fighting for the past 3 - 4 levels, yawn. As a work of art and putting a black spin on the original Alice in Wonderland fairytale, it's brilliant. But as a GAME it falls on its face and really sucks.

reviewText:
Things I liked about Alice Madness Returns:

- Different outfits for different worlds. It's the small details that I appreciate, and Alice has plenty of them. Just excellent !
- The visuals are some of the best I've ever seen (but the voice overs could use a little work at times).
- Skippable puzzles. I don't play chess, never have played it and don't intend on learning it so I was pleased to see that I could skip these puzzles altogether.
- Big worlds
- Enemies really do require different weapons and tactics

Things I disliked:

- It outstayed its welcome before it was over. Meaning it was overly long (yes, there is a thing as 'too long').
- Hitboxes were a disaster. There are times where you jump and crash into a barrier that isn't supposed to be there yet, where you slide, hit NOTHING and still get hit anyway and more silly things like that.
- The camera isn't always working properly.

Just a great action platformer, but with some minor, annoying, flaws.

[Rating: 75/100]

reviewText:
Excellent and engaging combat set in imaginative and dazzling worlds, with a marvellous soundtrack. Marred mostly by tedious and repetitive level design, frustrating camera and enemy lock-in issues, and a bit rough around the edges with regards to bugs and smooth controls. The minigames are a bit crap, too.

It's a dark, twisted little number with flowery writing and a fairly interesting, if predictable, story. The graphics aren't too bad but clearly aimed at consoles, but little features like Alice's hair and dress flowing as she moves adds a nice touch (I believe the game was a bit of a tech demo for Nvidia's hair rendering tech, but it looked nice enough on my AMD card).

If there was more emphasis on combat than platforming (The latter is so easy you'll be hard pressed to ever be challenged by it), I'd have probably enjoyed it much more, especially with the potential of enemy combinations they could have had.

Still, recommended, it's charming enough that boring and linear level design is at least eclipsed by good combat, writing, and art direction.

reviewText:
Pros:
+Amazing art style and idea.
Well, that sums it up for pros, now cons

So, cons.. yeah:
-Lets start with worthless PC port, shall we? 30 FPS lock. Barely any graphical and other options. In-game menu seems to be slow for some reason. While it's playable with keyboard, some parts of the game are not. Also, some button prompts are shown for Xbox controller, while it is not connected. This may lead to a quite frustation.
-It is, needlessly long and repetitive. The combat, the platforming, even plot elements seems to repeat themselves every chapter.
-Game also constantly fails to tell you some key moments, which can get you stuck sometimes.
-Most annoying and plain stupid minigames, thankfully, some of then can be skipped, but, unfortunately, not all of them. Seriously, did they actually think that it would be a good idea to throw in some qte, puzzles, 2d platforming or even pinball arcade !@#$ in the middle of an action? I can hardly imagine.
-The secrets are met so often, they become generic. Even worse, finding them don't seem to reward you in any way, shape or form. In fact, they make you take longer paths, which result in major waste of time. Well, sometimes you get enough stuff from secrets to upgrade your weapons, but you can do it without secrets. You can, however, upgrade your health via secrets only. But, you have to find so many, and it give you so little, you would not want even bother in the first place.
-Countless bugs and glitches. It's just terrible. Sometimes you have a cursor appear in game for some reason (they even multiply), other times Alice just starts running forward after cutscene or loadscreen and dies horribly in first pit.. yeah. Some invisible walls that you always hit every once in a while, some stuff glitch through, some enemies getting stuck in walls and you can't get them out, so u have to restart checkpoint. And so on and so forth. Countless, really.


Overall ~ I would love to like this game, but I can't. It caused me too much pain. It could have been a good.. no, amazing game, assuming the team had a decent programmers and level designers.

reviewText:
Published by EA, made by a bunch of Chinese, no offense.

The most annoying part during the whole game for me were the terrible but seriously. Horrible hitboxes.
This made the game harder then it actually was.
Besides that, the target switching when focussed was annoying too.
Also not knowing wich way to go, either it's the next step forward, or a secret level.
And sometimes you'd skip secrets knowingly you thought they were the next step to progress in the game instead of a secret, vise versa.
You could replay the entire level for the secrets but they're pretty useless anyway.
You could speedrun this game, although with all the bugs and annoying features i doubt it.

The good thing about this game;

It is a good platformer for casuals and an intresting story.
Although it's a bit mind boggling, it's a different approach you could say?
The graphics are good, the mini games sometimes really sucked because of the hitboxes.
The bossfights are easy.
What made the fights hard were just the ammount of HP they have and the creatures were kinda repetitive.

I still would recommend this game though.
And if there ever came to be a sequel i'd play it.
But i'll probabbly never re-play this game again.

7/10

reviewText:
This is one of the games I wish steam had a neutral rating for.

Pros:
Theme (Traveling through Alices shattered mind.)
Atmosphere (Nice and creepy, and each area has it's on feel to it.)
Visuals (Decent graphics with a unique style to them.)
Animation (Combat animation seemed fluid to me. Her hair sure has more animation that I expected.)
Costumes (Different one for every chapter it seems, one makes her look like Wednesday Addams.)
Story

Cons:
Gameplay, honestly just this but it's enough to have me not recommending it. The combat gets repetative since there only a few enemy times per level and only 4 weapons. The collectables feel pointless, in the beginning I'd hunt them down, by the middle I would get them if I could and at the end I was ignoring them completely. Even the memories are usually only a character from Alices life saying a single sentence or maybe two when you pick them up. The game seems like jumping puzzles and some hack n' slash wedged into a story. It felt more like the gameplay was a chore you had to do to get to the next bit of story, because the gameplay itself doesn't seem to tell much of the story.

Also the multijump function in the game screwed me over even when I did know what to do for the puzzle. You can jump in mid-air to gain height but if you don't do it at the perfect time she just spins in the air staying the same height, multiple times I watched her twirl right next to a ledge she was only maybe 2 under and then fall to her death. The side scroller bits in chapter 3 were really bad for this
date: trying to jump on a tiger statue head that's shooting fireballs at you only to barely fail the jump and get shot in the face.\n\nI enjoyed the feel of the game
recommended: the creepy atmosphere was really well done
hoursPlayed: if the gameplay elements don't sound that bad and it's on sale I wouldn't be against someone picking it up. But for full price I don't think it's worth it

reviewText:
This game has a low rating for a good reason, however, Ill just describe the area that I got stuck on.  It was in the mad hatters domain, near the end of it where there is a maze of pounding fists you need to navigate.  At the last part of this maze there is what I call a mini-boss area.  You jump past some pounding fists on to a ledge and there are a bunch of baddies around you need to defeat.

The big guy in the middle is a tough one you faced before where you had to block and/or reflect his attacks with an umbrella by hitting the E key.  However this game is so flaky 75% of the time when I hit the E key, nothing happened.  I could not harm this guy because he was blocking 100% of the times. I assume the trick was to bounce his bombs back at him, yet I could NEVER get that damn umbrelle to pop out when I wanted it to.

Further more there are a bunch of other things attacking you at this point.

This next part brings up another major annoyance.  Check point saves.  Now while this can be OK, it depends on the developer putting them in intellegent points.  You might think the right before and after a boss fight would qualify as MUST HAVE check points.

Not in this game.  Nope, if you fail the boss fight you have to do the ENTIRE AREA all over again.  I mean there is even a LOADING SCREEN betten the last save and the boss fight.  Thats how far it is.

After trying about 9 times on easy (I have no idea what that setting does, I lowed to the bottom just for this one fight) I gave up.

I paid $2.99 for the game.  Don't waste your money.  Its super linear and very unispiring.  The controls are very wonky and difficult to use in combat.  The camera is also wonky which is bad for a puzzle platformer.

reviewText: Hands down the best game I've played all year and most definitely one of the best games I've played ever.\nAmerican McGee has made an incredible comeback with this sequel. I fondly remember playing American McGee's Alice in high school but Madness Returns is volumes better in all aspects of concept, storyline, graphics, and gameplay. This game takes on more of a platform concept which incorporates plenty of jumping, twirling, and floating in the air. This is a beautiful psychological horror game with jaw dropping artwork and a very developed storyline. It is a highly grotesque game in all the right ways. Mcgee takes an even further step away from the classic Alice prototype and recreates an even more disturbing and grown up Wonderland. The fighting in this game is much more complex than the original and it is gorgeous to watch. The vorpal blade is the only returning weapon, but there are new and more exciting weapons including the hobby horse, which was probably my favourite addition. Alice's outfits change with her state of mind and the parts of Wonderland which she visits. There are mini-game" sections added throughout that are fun to play. Absolutely brilliant game. Highly recommend. 10/10"

reviewText:
Great game. A very creative and dark twist on the Alice in Wonderland world.

PROS:
-amazing surreal and often disturbing art design
-very dark and demented story with many adult themes (this is not a kid's game)

reviewText:
Alice: Madness Returns is the sequel to the cult hit American McGee's Alice. This is a game that takes the familiar wonderland and turns it on its head, making it a morbid, gruesome and dangerous place. In this game, Wonderland is the delusion of a disturbed girl who is seeking an escape from her dreary life and forgiveness for her failures.

Alice really delivers in terms of striking visuals and an art style that is reminiscent of the films of Tim Burton, but different enough that it doesn't feel like a direct imitation. Alice herself changes in each zone of the game, her dress taking on different elements of goth, S&M or Steampunk attire. Enemies and npcs are bizarre and magical and discovering more of them compels one to continue playing.

The only thing I dislike about Alice is how familiar it feels. It is very much an action platformer at its heart, with Alice taking on the monsters of Wonderland and of her own psyche with a magical butcher knife and a pepper grinder which acts as a machine gun. However, it is a very strong action platformer with plenty of hidden areas and challenging jumping puzzles that make the experience compelling, challenging and rewarding.

While the game is in a genre that I feel stopped being intresting in the early 2000s, Alice has interesting enough scenery and characters and a good enough overall story to keep most players interested. It is worth it for the visuals alone. Play this one if you want to play a fun, challenging game that is not too deep.

reviewText:
5/10

Not a very good game. While visually interesting at first, the polish and freshness runs out in the first half hour or so, and  the game turns into endless copy pasted envirnments. The screenshots above are not representative of the game as a whole, and that trailer is even worse. While I'm not one to gripe about graphics, the character models look and move like ps2 era npcs. The game also runs fairly poorly, with freezing and frame skipping on a regular basis, and whenever anything chaotic happens the game slows to a crawl. The enemy designs are not particularly varied, and the main type of enemy is repeated ad nosium, the only variants simply being bigger versions of the small ones. The plot is virtually none existant, and isn't communicated much to the player except through vague and incongruently drawn cutscenes. Perhaps those who played the original (or prequel? the relationship is unclear in this game) game American Mcgee's Alice would get more here, but as for this game on its own, practically no story. Voice acting gets irritating very quickly, especially the main npc's like hatter and march hare, and a lot of the clips sound like they don't even belong in the game (muted or too quiet, jumpy breaks between lines). The voice actress playing Alice sounds incredibly bored the whole time. Game play is straight forward and gets stale very quickly, and the few minigames end up being tedious. Platforming is not great, as alice's jumping mechanics are hard to control. A section around the middle in the souls locker area is particularly tedious thanks to the bad controls. Overall, a great first thirty minutes, but it overstays its welcome beyond that and becomes a generic, gray hack and slash. Might as well just play God of War or any other game with this exact formula.

TLDR: In conclusion, gray and generic.  Best parts are the menus and the first two areas. Runs like crap with bad controls. Mind numbing and time cocnsuming as it goes on, even the characters are bored. In a word, Mediocre.

reviewText:
Alice is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing phenomenal. Do you like gritty, atmospheric stories with tons of ambiance? Dark twists on children's stories? Goregous and elaborate set pieces with varied puzzles? Mind-blowingly fine-tuned combat that is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ic in every fight? Fresh and fun platformer mechanics in a 40-hour package without the torture of replaying a level every time you miss a jump?

Play Alice. This was easily the best impulse purchase I've ever made in my life.

---

I was going to leave this short and sweet, but seriously, dat combat system. The game focuses heavily on large brawls, where you'll be fighting 3, 5, even 10 enemies at once. There are dozens of enemy types and the devs keep things fresh by constantly changing up the mixture of enemies you're fighting. I have never played another game that captures the action-packed, cinematic feel of a large brawl as well as Alice. You will feel truly badass as you are weaving between enemies, stabbing one and then dodging his attack, switching to your hobby horse to pummel the next guy, tossing down a clock bomb, and then jumping to the edge of the fray and pummeling them with your pepper-grinder cannon. Your movement is extremely fast and fluid, your weapons precise, and overall everything about the combat is sex from start to finish.

I'm not the kind of person who writes reviews for anything, but I feel like people should know what they are getting into BEFORE they make the decision to purchase this game.

First things first:

1.  I chose not to recommend this based on the game-breaking bugs.  The plot is fantastic so far, and the worlds are gorgeous.  No gripes on that.

2.  Read the EULA. Apparently somewhere in there it mentions you MUST log in to an EA/Origin account. I didn't do this (I usually don't), and at my own expense--but I've chosen to ignore it partly because I wanted this game that badly.  I hate EA/Origin but for this game I tolerate the (so far) seemingly one-time login to EA/Origin.

3. If you are not great with understanding how to tweak the files of a game (even minimally), DO NOT waste your money.

Further Elaboration:

I have no idea who's at fault for the coding here, if I can even call it that, since I've never once had to do this in my life beforehand, or else be forced to give up on a game.  But within three hours of gameplay (at least one of those hours letting it idle on my computer while I looked up how to FIX the damned thing), it has become quite apparent that the game exhibits several crushing, game-breaking bugs.

The first (and so far, only game-breaking one I've witnessed) of these bugs happened to me when she picks up the umbrella to learn to block (NOTE: YOU CANNOT PROCEED FURTHER UNTIL SHE BLOCKS).  I understand it that if you don't change the standard controls (which, by the way, are utter crap for controls) that there shouldn't be any problem. Well, this was not the case for me. reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about this game. While I loved the first game, and I was looking forward to this one. However it just doesn't attach itself to you as much. And after a while you just get tired of it.

On a positive note, the graphics are much better and McGee's imagination is still quite active. But it's lost on a clunky game engine and bad design patterns that ruin the experience. I'd have enjoyed the game much more if not for the bad engine and design.

It's got most of the charm of the original Alice but you wouldn't like this one if you did't play the original. For example (spoiler), you get to see the mechanical version of the Mad Hatter, but you're never told why he's like that. They just assumed you knew that from the first game. It doesn't help that it feels like it's just a retelling of the first game (note: I haven't finished the game yet).

The first few stages let you get a feel of what the original Wonderland felt like, just like the first game. But they take you into the new Wonderland way too early and they show you what the new version looks like without you getting attached to the original. Unfortunately, the game doesn't have enough charm to keep you playing for long.

If you didn't pay the first before this, I suggest you start there. You'll enjoy this version more if you do that. If you did play the first, you could pick this game up on sale, but paying full price for it just doesn't feel right for me.

reviewText:
The only nice thing I will say, is that the art direction was well done. With that said, on with the rant...

The very first problem with this game is the ridiculous EA Login to verify the game. This alone would have prevented me from buying the game if I'd checked/been warned.

The level design is maddening. Keeping track of secret cubbies to collect memories was headache inducing. At times, I felt like the whole point was to collect memories and teeth, but luckily for me, the previously mentioned level design made that close to impossible to collect them all on the first go, even being extremely careful. Not that it matters since this game lacks achievements (GRRRRRR!)

The Voice Talent was weak. The main character comes off as spineless, which in this specific story makes her unlikeable. Talking about story, for a game this mediocre, a good story keeps people playing, but there wasn't even that to enjoy. I found myself wishing Wonderland would just be nuked into oblivion, just so that she'd stop whining.

I constantly felt like I was being sent on fetch quests, except when these happen in other platformers or MMORPGs you at least get some level of satisfaction for completion. Not in this game.

Unless your goal is to subject yourself to a Tim Burton-esque Mediocre Platformer, stay away from this game.

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong - there are moments of true brilliance, both visually and in terms of script, in this game. This is a propper arthouse game, no doubt about that. But to experience it all you must grind for hours and hours on end. The length of this thing is ridiculous. There are five chapters there. Sounds reasonable? Not so, unfortunately. The length extends enormously, because you will die/fail and retry hundreds (literally!) of times. When after a series of lengthy action/platforming sequences you think that you're finally at the end of the chapter, you're usually not even one third way through. The change of scenery helps combat this, but everything brakes down again when you are  forced to stay in the new environment for much longer than is actually required. This is irritating as hell. And the emphasis on arcade-like (and even 2D sidescrolling!) timed jumping - mind boggling. There is no proper feeling of flow at all here.

Sure, if you're a hardened gamer specializing in third person action games, get this game. You should have a blast! But if you are not (I myself have 20 years of experience, but mostly in first person action games), think twice. And if you do buy it, don't even contemplate playing it on anything but the easiest mode.

Developers of this thing should point their attention towards regular people next time and get rid of this tedious platforming and trial/error based mechanics of grinding out enormously drawn-out levels.

BTW, Steam says I'm 13+ hours in (actual number may be even higher, as usual), but in the game, I'm about 50% done. So for me this is a 25-30 hours game, and that is way too much for a story driven linnear action experience, imho.
